objects.name: $f(x)$
objects.type_and_definition: Monic irreducible polynomial in $\mathbb{Z}[x]$
objects.comment: The polynomial under investigation. It is monic (leading coefficient 1), irreducible over $\mathbb{Z}$, and has integer coefficients.

objects.name: $p$
objects.type_and_definition: Prime number
objects.comment: A prime number from the infinite set of primes satisfying the condition.

objects.name: $\mathbb{F}_p$
objects.type_and_definition: Finite field with $p$ elements
objects.comment: The field of integers modulo $p$.

objects.name: $f(x) = x^2 + 1$
objects.type_and_definition: Specific monic irreducible polynomial in $\mathbb{Z}[x]$, defined as $f(x) = x^2 + 1$
objects.comment: Serves as a counterexample to conjecture conj_001. It is monic, irreducible over $\mathbb{Z}$, and has the property that the congruence $f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod p$ has a solution for infinitely many primes $p$ (specifically, all primes $p \equiv 1 \pmod{4}$).

objects.name: $f(x) = x^3 - 2$
objects.type_and_definition: Specific monic irreducible polynomial in $\mathbb{Z}[x]$, defined as $f(x) = x^3 - 2$
objects.comment: Serves as a second counterexample to conjecture conj_001. It is monic, irreducible over $\mathbb{Z}$, and has the property that the congruence $f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod p$ has a solution for infinitely many primes $p$ (with density $2/3$ by Chebotarev).

objects.name: $\bar{f}_p(x)$
objects.type_and_definition: Polynomial over the finite field $\mathbb{F}_p$, obtained by applying the reduction map $\pi_p$ to $f(x)$.
objects.comment: The local avatar of $f$. Studying its factorization (especially existence of roots) modulo $p$ is the core of the problem. The conjecture concerns the statistics of when $\bar{f}_p$ has a linear factor.

objects.name: $S_f$ (or $\text{Split}_1(f)$)
objects.type_and_definition: Set of primes $p$ such that $\bar{f}_p(x)$ has at least one root in $\mathbb{F}_p$. Equivalently, $S_f = \{ p \text{ prime} : f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod p \text{ is solvable} \}$.
objects.comment: Directly encodes the hypothesis of the original conjecture (lem_002). Reframing the problem in terms of properties of $S_f$ (size, density) is crucial. The conjecture claimed: if $|S_f| = \infty$, then $\deg(f)=1$.

objects.name: $K = \mathbb{Q}(\theta)$
objects.type_and_definition: Number field generated by a complex root $\theta$ of $f(x)$. Since $f$ is irreducible over $\mathbb{Z}$ (hence over $\mathbb{Q}$), $K$ is a finite algebraic extension of $\mathbb{Q}$.
objects.comment: The global field containing all algebraic information about $f$. Connects polynomial congruences to prime splitting in $\mathcal{O}_K$: $p \in S_f$ corresponds roughly to $p$ having a degree-1 prime ideal factor in $\mathcal{O}_K$. Essential for applying Chebotarev density theorem.

objects.name: $\mathcal{P}_n$
objects.type_and_definition: For fixed integer $n \ge 1$, $\mathcal{P}_n = \{ f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x] : f \text{ is monic, irreducible, and } \deg(f) = n \}$.
objects.comment: Parameterizes monic irreducible polynomials by degree. Testing the conjecture by degree: the original claim would imply that for any $f \in \mathcal{P}_n$ with $n>1$, $S_f$ is finite. Counterexamples like $x^2+1 \in \mathcal{P}_2$ show this is false.

objects.name: $\mathrm{FPP}(G, X)$
objects.type_and_definition: For a finite group $G$ acting on a finite set $X$, $\mathrm{FPP}(G, X)$ is the proportion of group elements that have at least one fixed point in $X$. That is, $\mathrm{FPP}(G, X) = \frac{ |\{ g \in G : \mathrm{Fix}(g) \neq \emptyset \} | }{ |G| }$.
objects.comment: This object quantifies the connection between group action and the density $d(f)$. For a polynomial $f$ with Galois group $G$ acting on the roots $X$, we have $d(f) = \mathrm{FPP}(G, X)$. The extreme condition $d(f) = 1$ corresponds to $\mathrm{FPP}(G, X) = 1$, i.e., the fixed-point covering property.

objects.name: $E_f$
objects.type_and_definition: Set of primes $p$ (unramified in the splitting field of $f$) such that $f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod p$ has NO solution in $\mathbb{F}_p$. Formally, $E_f = \{ p \text{ prime (unramified)} : 1 \notin T_p(f) \}$, where $T_p(f)$ is the decomposition type.
objects.comment: The complement of $S_f$ (excluding ramified primes). Studying $E_f$ provides a dual perspective to $S_f$. Natural questions: Does $E_f$ always have positive density when $d(f) < 1$? Can it be described by congruence conditions for abelian Galois groups? This connects to exploration direction dir_004 and the minimal density problem.

objects.name: $D_n$
objects.type_and_definition: For fixed integer $n \ge 2$, $D_n = \{ d \in [0, 1] : \exists f(x) \in \mathcal{P}_n \text{ (monic, irreducible, deg=$n$)} \text{ such that } d(f) = d \}$, where $d(f)$ is the natural density of $S_f$.
objects.comment: The density spectrum for degree $n$ is now precisely characterized: $D_n = \{ \rho(G) : G \in \mathcal{G}_n \text{ and } G \text{ is realizable as a Galois group over } \mathbb{Q} \}$, where $\rho(G)$ is the fixed-point proportion. Explicit values for $n=2,3,4$ are given. The classification theorem (lem_009) is confirmed and extended.

objects.name: $\delta: \mathcal{P}_n \to D_n$
objects.type_and_definition: Function mapping each monic irreducible polynomial $f$ of degree $n$ to its associated density $d(f)$. Formally, $\delta(f) = d(f)$, where $d(f)$ is the natural density of $S_f$.
objects.comment: The density function on the parameter space $\mathcal{P}_n$. Studying $\delta$ asks: How does density vary across the space of degree-$n$ polynomials? Is there a 'generic' density (e.g., for polynomials with Galois group $S_n$, density tends to $1 - 1/e$ as $n\to\infty$)? This connects to arithmetic statistics and probabilistic Galois theory.

objects.name: $\Gamma_G$
objects.type_and_definition: For a transitive permutation group $G$ acting on a set $X$ of $n$ elements, define a directed graph $\Gamma_G$ where vertices are elements $g \in G$, and there is a directed edge from $g$ to $h$ if $\operatorname{Fix}(g) \subseteq \operatorname{Fix}(h)$. An undirected version connects $g$ and $h$ if $\operatorname{Fix}(g) \cap \operatorname{Fix}(h) \neq \emptyset$.
objects.comment: The fixed-point graph models the network of shared fixed-point structure within the Galois group. It provides a novel graph-theoretic tool to analyze intermediate conditions between 'some element has a fixed point' ($d(f)>0$) and 'every element has a fixed point' ($d(f)=1$). Potential investigations: connectivity properties related to density thresholds, characterization of complete graphs (common fixed point).

objects.name: $T_p(f)$
objects.type_and_definition: For a prime $p$ unramified in the splitting field of $f$, let $\bar{f}_p(x)$ factor into irreducibles over $\mathbb{F}_p$ with degrees $d_1, d_2, \dots, d_k$ where $\sum d_i = n = \deg(f)$. The decomposition type $T_p(f)$ is the multiset (partition of $n$) $[d_1, d_2, \dots, d_k]$.
objects.comment: Records the full local splitting behavior of $f$ modulo $p$, not just existence of a root. $S_f = \{ p : 1 \in T_p(f) \}$, $E_f = \{ p : 1 \notin T_p(f) \}$. Chebotarev's theorem gives densities for each possible $T_p(f)$ corresponding to conjugacy classes in the Galois group. This object enables a more granular analysis than just $S_f$.

objects.name: $\rho(G)$
objects.type_and_definition: For a finite permutation group $G$ acting on a set $X$, $\rho(G) = \frac{|\{g \in G : g \text{ fixes at least one element of } X\}|}{|G|}$, i.e., the fixed-point proportion.
objects.comment: This is the fixed-point proportion of a permutation group. In the context of Galois groups of polynomials, it equals the density $d(f)$. The new text provides a complete classification: the set of possible densities for degree $n$ is exactly the set of $\rho(G)$ for transitive $G$ of degree $n$ realizable over $\mathbb{Q}$. Explicit values for small $n$ are computed.

objects.name: $\rho(G)$ (or $d_G$)
objects.type_and_definition: For a finite permutation group $G$ acting on a finite set $X$, define $\rho(G) = \frac{|\{ g \in G : \text{Fix}(g) \ge 1 \}|}{|G|}$, where $\text{Fix}(g) = |\{ x \in X : g(x) = x \}|$.
objects.comment: This is the fixed-point proportion of a permutation group. In the context of Galois groups of polynomials, it equals the density $d(f)$. The new text provides a complete classification: the set of possible densities for degree $n$ is exactly the set of $\rho(G)$ for transitive $G$ of degree $n$ realizable over $\mathbb{Q}$. Explicit values for small $n$ are computed.

objects.name: $\mathcal{G}_n$
objects.type_and_definition: The set of all transitive permutation groups of degree $n$ (up to permutation isomorphism).
objects.comment: This set is finite for each $n$. The possible densities for degree-$n$ polynomials are $\{ \rho(G) : G \in \mathcal{G}_n \text{ and } G \text{ is realizable as a Galois group over } \mathbb{Q} \}$. This object parameterizes the group-theoretic input to the density classification.

objects.name: $d_{\min}(n)$
objects.type_and_definition: Function from integers $n \geq 2$ to rational numbers, defined as $d_{\min}(n) = \min \{ d(f) : f \in \mathcal{P}_n \}$, where $\mathcal{P}_n$ is the set of monic irreducible polynomials of degree $n$ and $d(f)$ is the natural density of $S_f$.
objects.comment: The minimum possible density for degree $n$. Conjectured to be $1/n$, attained by polynomials with cyclic Galois group $C_n$. This object formalizes the extremal problem in Direction 3.

objects.name: $d_{\max}(n)$
objects.type_and_definition: Function from integers $n \geq 2$ to rational numbers, defined as $d_{\max}(n) = \max \{ d(f) : f \in \mathcal{P}_n \}$, where $\mathcal{P}_n$ is the set of monic irreducible polynomials of degree $n$ and $d(f)$ is the natural density of $S_f$.
objects.comment: The maximum possible density for degree $n$. For small $n$: $d_{\max}(2)=1/2$, $d_{\max}(3)=2/3$, $d_{\max}(4)=3/4$. Asymptotically conjectured to approach $1 - e^{-1}$ from below, achieved by polynomials with Galois group $S_n$ or $A_n$. This object formalizes the extremal problem in Direction 3.

objects.name: $\mathcal{A}_f$
objects.type_and_definition: For a monic irreducible polynomial $f$ with abelian Galois group, $\mathcal{A}_f$ is the subset of $(\mathbb{Z}/N_f\mathbb{Z})^\times$ such that for primes $p \nmid N_f$, $p \in E_f$ if and only if $p \bmod N_f \in \mathcal{A}_f$. Here $N_f$ is the conductor of the abelian extension associated to $f$.
objects.comment: Provides explicit congruence characterization of $E_f$ for abelian cases. Connects to Kronecker-Weber and class field theory. Introduced in the deep exploration of dir_008.

objects.name: $\mathcal{C}_{\text{der}}(G)$
objects.type_and_definition: For a permutation group $G$, the set of conjugacy classes in $G$ consisting of derangements (elements with no fixed points). Formally, $\mathcal{C}_{\text{der}}(G) = \{C \subseteq G : C \text{ is a conjugacy class}, \forall g \in C, \operatorname{Fix}(g) = \emptyset\}$.
objects.comment: Key to describing $E_f$ via Chebotarev: $E_f$ (up to finite exceptions) consists of primes whose Frobenius lies in $\bigcup \mathcal{C}_{\text{der}}(G)$. Introduced in the deep exploration of dir_008.

objects.name: $\Phi_n$
objects.type_and_definition: Function $\Phi_n: \mathcal{G}_n^{\text{real}} \to D_n$, where $\mathcal{G}_n^{\text{real}}$ is the set of transitive permutation groups of degree $n$ realizable as Galois groups over $\mathbb{Q}$, defined by $\Phi_n(G) = \rho(G)$, the fixed-point proportion of $G$.
objects.comment: This function explicitly maps each realizable Galois group to its associated arithmetic density. Studying its fibers (groups with the same $\rho(G)$) is crucial for the inverse problem of constructing polynomials with a given density (dir_014, dir_016). Example: For $n=4$, $\Phi_4(C_4)=\Phi_4(V_4)=1/4$, showing non-injectivity.

objects.name: $E'_f(\pi)$
objects.type_and_definition: For a monic irreducible polynomial $f$ of degree $n$ and a partition $\pi$ of $n$ that does not contain the part $1$, $E'_f(\pi)$ is the set of primes $p$ (unramified in the splitting field of $f$) such that the decomposition type $T_p(f)$ equals $\pi$. Formally, $E'_f(\pi) = \{ p \text{ prime (unramified)} : T_p(f) = \pi \}$.
objects.comment: A refinement of $E_f$ that splits the exceptional primes by their full splitting type. Provides a finer lens for applying Chebotarev density theorem. The density of $E'_f(\pi)$ is $|C_\pi|/|G|$, where $C_\pi$ is the conjugacy class in the Galois group $G$ corresponding to cycle type $\pi$. Studying these subsets enables more precise versions of conj_004 and extremal problems for specific splitting types.

objects.name: $\mathcal{P}_n(H)$
objects.type_and_definition: For integers $n \geq 1$ and $H \geq 1$, $\mathcal{P}_n(H) = \{ f(x) = x^n + a_{n-1}x^{n-1} + \cdots + a_0 \in \mathbb{Z}[x] : |a_i| \leq H \text{ for all } i, \text{ and } f \text{ is monic and irreducible} \}$
objects.comment: A finite subset of $\mathcal{P}_n$ parameterized by coefficient bound $H$. Essential for statistical analysis, as we consider limits as $H \to \infty$. This object allows us to talk about 'random polynomials' and their properties.

objects.name: $\mu_n$
objects.type_and_definition: The asymptotic density measure on $\mathcal{P}_n$ defined by $\mu_n(E) = \lim_{H \to \infty} \frac{|E \cap \mathcal{P}_n(H)|}{|\mathcal{P}_n(H)|}$ for suitable subsets $E \subseteq \mathcal{P}_n$, when the limit exists.
objects.comment: Formalizes the notion of 'generic' behavior. Under $\mu_n$, almost all polynomials have Galois group $S_n$ and density $\rho(S_n)$. This measure is crucial for probabilistic statements about polynomial properties.

objects.name: $\mathcal{G}_n^{\max}$
objects.type_and_definition: For each integer $n \ge 2$, $\mathcal{G}_n^{\max} = \{ G \in \mathcal{G}_n^{\mathbb{Q}} : \rho(G) = \max_{H \in \mathcal{G}_n^{\mathbb{Q}}} \rho(H) \}$, where $\mathcal{G}_n^{\mathbb{Q}}$ is the set of transitive permutation groups of degree $n$ realizable as Galois groups over $\mathbb{Q}$, and $\rho(G)$ is the fixed-point proportion.
objects.comment: Captures the extremal groups that achieve the maximum possible density $d_{\max}(n)$ for degree $n$. Known: $\mathcal{G}_2^{\max}=\{S_2\}$, $\mathcal{G}_3^{\max}=\{S_3\}$, $\mathcal{G}_4^{\max}=\{A_4\}$. Determining $\mathcal{G}_n^{\max}$ for $n\ge5$ is an open problem.

objects.name: $\pi_{f, \pi}(N)$
objects.type_and_definition: Counting function for a monic irreducible polynomial $f$ of degree $n$ and a partition $\pi$ of $n$ not containing 1. Defined as $\pi_{f, \pi}(N) = |\{ p \le N : p \text{ unramified in the splitting field of } f, \text{ and the decomposition type } T_p(f) = \pi \}|$.
objects.comment: Refines the counting of primes in the exceptional set $E_f$ by splitting type. Essential for studying the distribution within $E_f$ and connecting to the densities of the subsets $E'_f(\pi)$. Used in the deep exploration of dir_008 to analyze fluctuations and dominant types.

objects.name: $\Phi_n^{-1}(r)$ (fiber of $\Phi_n$)
objects.type_and_definition: For a rational number $r \in D_n$, the fiber $\Phi_n^{-1}(r) = \{ G \in \mathcal{G}_n^{\text{real}} : \rho(G) = r \}$, where $\mathcal{G}_n^{\text{real}}$ is the set of transitive permutation groups of degree $n$ realizable as Galois groups over $\mathbb{Q}$, and $\Phi_n(G) = \rho(G)$.
objects.comment: These fibers partition the set of realizable Galois groups into density-equivalence classes. Studying their size and structure addresses the inverse problem: given a density $r$, which Galois groups could a polynomial with that density have? For $n=4$, fibers are $\Phi_4^{-1}(1/4)=\{C_4, V_4\}$, $\Phi_4^{-1}(5/8)=\{D_4, S_4\}$, $\Phi_4^{-1}(3/4)=\{A_4\}$.

objects.name: $\Psi_n$
objects.type_and_definition: Function mapping from the set of realizable transitive permutation groups of degree $n$ and their unions of conjugacy classes to the density spectrum $D_n$. Formally, $\Psi_n: \mathcal{G}_n^{\text{real}} \times \mathcal{C}(G) \to D_n$, where $\mathcal{G}_n^{\text{real}}$ is the set of transitive permutation groups of degree $n$ realizable as Galois groups over $\mathbb{Q}$, and for $G \in \mathcal{G}_n^{\text{real}}$, $\mathcal{C}(G)$ is the set of all unions of conjugacy classes of $G$ that correspond to intermediate fields via Galois correspondence. The map sends $(G, U)$ to $\rho_U(G) = |U|/|G|$.
objects.comment: Generalizes $\Phi_n$ (obj_023) by considering densities arising from arbitrary unions of conjugacy classes (e.g., different splitting conditions). Provides a framework for the inverse problem (dir_014, dir_016) and refines the relationship between Galois structure and density (dir_011).

objects.name: $\Delta_{\min}(n, r)$
objects.type_and_definition: Function from integers $n \ge 2$ and rational numbers $r \in D_n$ to non-negative integers (or infinity). Defined as $\Delta_{\min}(n, r) = \min \{ |\Delta_f| : f \in \mathcal{P}_n, \ d(f) = r \}$, where $\Delta_f$ is the discriminant of $f$. If no polynomial achieves density $r$, define $\Delta_{\min}(n, r) = \infty$.
objects.comment: Measures the minimal discriminant among polynomials of degree $n$ with a given density $r$. Connects algebraic density classification to analytic complexity (via effective Chebotarev). Provides a quantitative refinement of the explicit construction problem (dir_016).

objects.name: $N_n(r; H)$
objects.type_and_definition: Function from integers $n \ge 2$, rational $r \in D_n$, and positive integer $H$ to non-negative integers. Defined as $N_n(r; H) = \left| \{ f \in \mathcal{P}_n(H) : d(f) = r \} \right|$, where $\mathcal{P}_n(H)$ is the set of monic irreducible polynomials of degree $n$ with coefficients bounded by $H$ (obj_025).
objects.comment: Counts polynomials of bounded height with a given density. Enables fine statistical analysis of the density function $\delta$ (obj_013) and addresses quantitative aspects of generic behavior (dir_010) and convergence rates (conj_011).

objects.name: $\operatorname{Aut}(L(G))$
objects.type_and_definition: For a transitive permutation group $G$ acting on a set $X$ of size $n$, with fixed-point lattice $L(G)$ (con_023), define $\operatorname{Aut}(L(G))$ as the group of all lattice automorphisms $\phi: L(G) \to L(G)$, i.e., bijections preserving the inclusion order.
objects.comment: Measures the symmetry of the fixed-point lattice structure. May help characterize when distinct groups share the same fixed-point proportion $\rho(G)$ (density-equivalence) and relates to the fixed-point graph $\Gamma_G$ (obj_014).

objects.name: $N_f^{\min}$
objects.type_and_definition: For a monic irreducible polynomial $f$ with abelian Galois group, $N_f^{\min}$ is the smallest positive integer $N$ such that the exceptional set $E_f$ can be described, up to finitely many primes, as $E_f = \{ p \text{ prime} : p \bmod N \in \mathcal{A} \}$ for some subset $\mathcal{A} \subseteq (\mathbb{Z}/N\mathbb{Z})^\times$.
objects.comment: The minimal modulus for the abelian exceptional set $E_f$. A canonical invariant quantifying the periodicity of primes where $f$ has no root. Connects to the conductor of the associated cyclotomic field and refines the study of $E_f$ structure (dir_008). The new object $N_f^{\text{ab}}$ is an explicit specialization and naming for the abelian case, prompting focused quantitative study.

objects.name: $\gamma(\epsilon)$
objects.type_and_definition: Function from positive real numbers $\epsilon > 0$ to extended natural numbers $\mathbb{N} \cup \{\infty\}$. Defined as $\gamma(\epsilon) = \sup \{ n \in \mathbb{N} : \text{there exists } f \in \mathcal{P}_n \text{ with } d(f) > 1 - \epsilon \}$, or equivalently, $\gamma(\epsilon) = \max \{ n : D_n \cap (1-\epsilon, 1) \neq \emptyset \}$.
objects.comment: Quantifies the gap near 1 in the density spectrum $D = \bigcup_n D_n$. Directly addresses the gap problem (dir_015, dir_021) and conjecture conj_013. Finite $\gamma(\epsilon)$ for all $\epsilon>0$ implies a uniform upper bound $c<1$ on $d(f)$ for nonlinear $f$.

objects.name: $f(x) = x^6 + x^3 + 1$
objects.type_and_definition: Specific monic irreducible polynomial in $\mathbb{Z}[x]$, defined as $f(x) = x^6 + x^3 + 1$. It is the cyclotomic polynomial $\Phi_9(x)$.
objects.comment: Proposed explicit example for minimal density in degree 6. Its Galois group is cyclic $C_6$, so $d(f)=1/6$. Useful for empirical verification and studying abelian exceptional set $E_f$ (conductor 9).

objects.name: $X_{N,H}(f)$
objects.type_and_definition: Random variable defined for $f \in \mathcal{P}_n(H)$ as $X_{N,H}(f) = \pi_f(N) - \rho(S_n) \cdot \pi(N)$, where $\pi_f(N)$ counts primes $p \le N$ with $p \in S_f$, and $\pi(N)$ counts all primes $\le N$.
objects.comment: Measures deviation of the prime count from the generic density expectation. Central to studying variance across random polynomials (new direction).

objects.name: $\rho_{\max}(n)$
objects.type_and_definition: Function from integers $n \ge 2$ to rational numbers, defined as $\rho_{\max}(n) = \max \{ \rho(G) : G \text{ is a transitive permutation group of degree } n \}$.
objects.comment: Theoretical maximum fixed-point proportion among all transitive groups of degree $n$ (not necessarily realizable over $\mathbb{Q}$). Studying its asymptotics addresses the density gap problem.

objects.name: $\mathcal{Q}_4(H)$
objects.type_and_definition: For integer $H \geq 1$, $\mathcal{Q}_4(H) = \{ f(x) = x^4 + a x^3 + b x^2 + c x + d \in \mathbb{Z}[x] : |a|,|b|,|c|,|d| \leq H, \text{ and } f \text{ is monic and irreducible} \}$
objects.comment: A finite subset of $\mathcal{P}_4$ (monic irreducible quartics) parameterized by coefficient bound $H$. Enables statistical analysis of Galois group distribution and density values among quartics with small coefficients. This is the degree-4 specialization of $\mathcal{P}_n(H)$ (obj_025).

objects.name: $\pi_f(N; \text{root})$
objects.type_and_definition: For a monic irreducible polynomial $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ and positive integer $N$, $\pi_f(N; \text{root}) = |\{ p \leq N : p \text{ prime}, f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod{p} \text{ has a solution in } \mathbb{F}_p \}| = |\{ p \leq N : p \in S_f \}|$
objects.comment: The prime counting function restricted to primes where $f$ has a root modulo $p$. Empirical approximation to $d(f) \cdot \pi(N)$. Used to verify theoretical densities from Chebotarev theorem.

objects.name: $\text{Err}_f(N)$
objects.type_and_definition: For a monic irreducible polynomial $f$ and $N > 0$, $\text{Err}_f(N) = \left| \frac{\pi_f(N; \text{root})}{\pi(N)} - d(f) \right|$, where $d(f)$ is the theoretical density from $\rho(G)$
objects.comment: Measures the empirical error in density estimation from finite prime counting. Quantifies the convergence rate in Chebotarev density theorem for specific polynomials.

objects.name: $\Delta_{\min}(G; H)$
objects.type_and_definition: Function from a realizable transitive permutation group $G$ of degree $n$ and a height bound $H > 0$ to a non-negative integer. Defined as $\Delta_{\min}(G; H) = \min \{ |\Delta_f| : f \in \mathcal{P}_n(H), \operatorname{Gal}(f) \cong G \}$, where $\mathcal{P}_n(H)$ is the set of monic irreducible polynomials of degree $n$ with coefficients bounded by $H$ (obj_025) and $\Delta_f$ is the discriminant of $f$.
objects.comment: Refines $\Delta_{\min}(n, r)$ (obj_031) by minimizing discriminant over polynomials with a specific Galois group $G$, not just a density $r$. Addresses explicit inverse Galois theory: 'What is the simplest (smallest discriminant) polynomial with Galois group $G$?' Connects algebraic complexity directly to Galois structure. Potential studies: growth with $H$, correlation with $\rho(G)$, and comparison across groups.

objects.name: $P_f$ (or $P_G$)
objects.type_and_definition: For a monic irreducible polynomial $f$ of degree $n$ with Galois group $G$, the prime splitting poset $P_f$ is a partially ordered set (or its Hasse diagram) whose elements are conjugacy classes (or unions thereof) of $G$, ordered by inclusion of fixed-point sets: for conjugacy classes $C_1, C_2$, define $C_1 \preceq C_2$ if $\operatorname{Fix}(g_1) \subseteq \operatorname{Fix}(g_2)$ for some (equivalently all) representatives $g_1 \in C_1$, $g_2 \in C_2$. The poset encodes relationships between different local splitting types $T_p(f)$.
objects.comment: Synthesizes individual splitting types ($E'_f(\pi)$, obj_024) and the fixed-point lattice $L(G)$ (con_023) into a global structure. Models logical implications between Frobenius conditions (e.g., having a root vs. having a linear factor). Expected to depend only on $G$ (so write $P_G$). Useful for systematic computation of densities for complex splitting conditions and for understanding the lattice of possible local data.

objects.name: $N_f^{\text{ab}}$
objects.type_and_definition: For a monic irreducible polynomial $f$ with abelian Galois group, $N_f^{\text{ab}}$ is the minimal positive integer $N$ such that the exceptional set $E_f$ (up to a finite set) is a union of arithmetic progressions modulo $N$. That is, $E_f = \{ p \text{ prime (unramified)} : p \bmod N \in \mathcal{A} \} \cup \text{(finite set)}$ for some $\mathcal{A} \subseteq (\mathbb{Z}/N\mathbb{Z})^\times$, and $N$ is minimal with this property.
objects.comment: Explicit refinement of $N_f^{\min}$ (obj_034) for the abelian case. A fundamental invariant of the abelian extension, closely related to the conductor. Prompts quantitative study: relation to discriminant $\Delta_f$, computability from coefficients, possible values for given degree $n$. Turns the qualitative theorem (lem_014) into a quantitative research problem, aiding explicit construction for the inverse problem.

objects.name: $A(r)$
objects.type_and_definition: Function from rational numbers $r \in (0,1)$ to positive integers or infinity. Defined as $A(r) = \min \{ n \ge 2 : r \in D_n \}$, where $D_n$ is the density spectrum for degree $n$ (obj_012). If no such $n$ exists, $A(r) = \infty$. $A(r)$ is the minimal degree needed to realize a given density $r$ by a monic irreducible polynomial.
objects.comment: The minimal degree needed to realize a given density $r$. Also denoted $\nu(r)$ and $\operatorname{mindeg}(r)$. Known values: $A(1/2)=2$, $A(1/3)=3$, $A(2/3)=3$, $A(1/4)=4$, $A(5/8)=4$, $A(3/4)=4$, $A(3/5)=5$. The new text provides an algorithmic sketch for computing $A(r)$ via enumeration of transitive groups and realizability checks, and gives explicit polynomial examples for several $r$.

objects.name: $\mathcal{E}_f(N)$
objects.type_and_definition: Normalized error term defined as $\mathcal{E}_f(N) = \frac{\pi_f(N) - d(f) \operatorname{Li}(N)}{\sqrt{N} \log N}$, where $\pi_f(N) = |\{p \le N : p \in S_f\}|$, $d(f)$ is the natural density of $S_f$, and $\operatorname{Li}(N)$ is the logarithmic integral.
objects.comment: Captures the scaled deviation of the prime count from its expected value under the Chebotarev density theorem. Under GRH, $\mathcal{E}_f(N)$ is bounded as $N \to \infty$. Studying its distribution (limit points, mean, variance) is a refined analytic problem central to dir_017.

objects.name: $\Lambda(f)$
objects.type_and_definition: Logarithmic discriminant of the splitting field of $f$, defined as $\Lambda(f) = \log |\Delta_L|$, where $L$ is the splitting field of $f$ and $\Delta_L$ is its discriminant.
objects.comment: A key complexity measure for the polynomial. Under GRH, the error term $E_f(N) = \pi_f(N) - d(f) \operatorname{Li}(N)$ is essentially proportional to $\Lambda(f) \sqrt{N} \log N$. Relates to the size of the Galois group and ramification data, influencing the variance in prime counting.

objects.name: $\mathcal{G}_n^{\text{known}}$
objects.type_and_definition: For a fixed integer $n \ge 2$, $\mathcal{G}_n^{\text{known}}$ is the set of transitive permutation groups $G$ of degree $n$ that are known (by current mathematical literature) to be realizable as the Galois group of a polynomial over $\mathbb{Q}$. This is a subset of the full set $\mathcal{G}_n$ (obj_018).
objects.comment: Formalizes the practical, knowledge-dependent approximation to the ideal set $\mathcal{G}_n^{\mathbb{Q}}$. Allows conditional results: $D_n^{\text{known}} = \{\rho(G) : G \in \mathcal{G}_n^{\text{known}}\} \subseteq D_n$. Essential for computational enumeration of density spectra given current inverse Galois knowledge.

objects.name: $\rho_{\max}^{\text{theor}}(n)$
objects.type_and_definition: Function from integers $n \ge 2$ to rational numbers, defined as $\rho_{\max}^{\text{theor}}(n) = \max \{ \rho(G) : G \text{ is a transitive permutation group of degree } n \}$, where $\rho(G)$ is the fixed-point proportion.
objects.comment: Purely group-theoretic extremal function providing an absolute upper bound for $d_{\max}(n)$: $d_{\max}(n) \le \rho_{\max}^{\text{theor}}(n)$. Studying its asymptotics informs the gap problem without the realizability obstruction.

objects.name: $\mathcal{G}_n^{\text{max-real}}$
objects.type_and_definition: For each integer $n \ge 2$, $\mathcal{G}_n^{\text{max-real}}$ is the set of transitive permutation groups $G$ of degree $n$ that are realizable as Galois groups over $\mathbb{Q}$ and satisfy $\rho(G) = d_{\max}(n)$. That is, $\mathcal{G}_n^{\text{max-real}} = \{ G \in \mathcal{G}_n^{\mathbb{Q}} : \rho(G) = \max_{H \in \mathcal{G}_n^{\mathbb{Q}}} \rho(H) \}$.
objects.comment: Precisely captures the Galois-theoretic solution to the maximum density problem for degree $n$. Known: $\mathcal{G}_2^{\text{max-real}}=\{S_2\}$, $\mathcal{G}_3^{\text{max-real}}=\{S_3\}$, $\mathcal{G}_4^{\text{max-real}}=\{A_4\}$, $\mathcal{G}_5^{\text{max-real}}=\{F_{20}\}$. Determining this set is equivalent to finding $d_{\max}(n)$.

objects.name: $\nu(r)$
objects.type_and_definition:
Function from rational numbers $r \in (0,1)$ to positive integers or infinity. Defined as $
u(r) = \min \{ n \ge 2 : r \in D_n \}$ if $r \in D$, and $
u(r) = \infty$ if $r 
otin D$, where $D_n$ is the density spectrum for degree $n$ (obj_012) and $D =  igcup_{n\ge2} D_n$.
objects.comment:
Directly answers the 'minimal degree' part of dir_014 (the inverse density problem). Encodes the complexity of realizing a given density. Known values: $
u(1/2)=2$, $
u(1/3)=3$, $
u(2/3)=3$, $
u(1/4)=4$, $
u(5/8)=4$, $
u(3/4)=4$. Computing $
u(r)$ for other rationals is a concrete computational task. This object is essentially the same as $A(r)$ (obj_045) but with a different name; we will merge them.

objects.name: $T_n$
objects.type_and_definition: For each integer $n \ge 2$, $T_n$ is a finite set of pairs $\{ (G, \rho(G)) : G \in \mathcal{G}_n^{\text{real}} \}$, where $\mathcal{G}_n^{\text{real}}$ is the set of transitive permutation groups of degree $n$ realizable as Galois groups over $\mathbb{Q}$, and $\rho(G)$ is the fixed-point proportion.
objects.comment: Organizes the mapping from realizable Galois groups to their densities for quick lookup. Essential for solving the inverse density problem (dir_016) algorithmically. For $n=5$, $T_5 = \{ (C_5, 1/5), (D_5, 3/5), (F_{20}, 11/20), (A_5, 3/5), (S_5, 19/30) \}$.

objects.name: $\operatorname{mindeg}(r)$
objects.type_and_definition: Function from the density spectrum $D = \bigcup_{n\ge2} D_n$ to positive integers, defined by $\operatorname{mindeg}(r) = \min \{ n \ge 2 : r \in D_n \}$.
objects.comment: Answers the minimal degree part of dir_016. Known values: $\operatorname{mindeg}(1/2)=2$, $\operatorname{mindeg}(2/3)=3$, $\operatorname{mindeg}(3/4)=4$, $\operatorname{mindeg}(3/5)=5$. This is essentially the same as $\nu(r)$ (obj_045) and $A(r)$ (obj_045), but with a distinct name; we will merge the concepts.

concepts.name: Monic polynomial
concepts.definition: A polynomial whose leading coefficient (the coefficient of the highest-degree term) is 1.
concepts.comment: Standard algebraic concept.

concepts.name: Irreducible polynomial over $\mathbb{Z}$
concepts.definition: A non-constant polynomial $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ that cannot be factored into the product of two non-constant polynomials in $\mathbb{Z}[x]$.
concepts.comment: Standard concept in ring theory; irreducibility over $\mathbb{Z}$ implies irreducibility over $\mathbb{Q}$ by Gauss's Lemma.

concepts.name: Polynomial congruence modulo $p$
concepts.definition: For a polynomial $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ and a prime $p$, the congruence $f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod p$ means that there exists an integer $a$ such that $p$ divides $f(a)$. Equivalently, the polynomial $\bar{f}(x) \in \mathbb{F}_p[x]$ (obtained by reducing coefficients modulo $p$) has a root in $\mathbb{F}_p$.
concepts.comment: Central to the problem's condition. Can now be formally restated using the reduction map $\pi_p$: $f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod p$ has a solution iff $\bar{f}_p(x)$ has a root in $\mathbb{F}_p$.

concepts.name: Quadratic residue modulo $p$
concepts.definition: For a prime $p$ and an integer $a$ not divisible by $p$, $a$ is a quadratic residue modulo $p$ if there exists an integer $x$ such that $x^2 \equiv a \pmod p$. Otherwise, $a$ is a quadratic nonresidue.
concepts.comment: Standard concept in number theory. Used in the proof to characterize when $x^2 + 1 \equiv 0 \pmod p$ has a solution: it is equivalent to $-1$ being a quadratic residue modulo $p$.

concepts.name: Legendre symbol $\left(\frac{a}{p}\right)$
concepts.definition: For an odd prime $p$ and integer $a$, the Legendre symbol $\left(\frac{a}{p}\right)$ is defined as: $0$ if $p \mid a$; $1$ if $a$ is a quadratic residue modulo $p$ and $p \nmid a$; $-1$ if $a$ is a quadratic nonresidue modulo $p$ and $p \nmid a$.
concepts.comment: Standard notation in number theory. Used to state quadratic reciprocity: $\left(\frac{-1}{p}\right) = (-1)^{(p-1)/2}$, which equals $1$ if $p \equiv 1 \pmod{4}$ and $-1$ if $p \equiv 3 \pmod{4}$.

concepts.name: Dirichlet's theorem on primes in arithmetic progressions
concepts.definition: If $a$ and $d$ are coprime positive integers, then the arithmetic progression $a, a+d, a+2d, \dots$ contains infinitely many prime numbers.
concepts.comment: A fundamental theorem in analytic number theory. Used in the proof to guarantee infinitely many primes $p \equiv 1 \pmod{4}$, which are exactly the primes for which $x^2 + 1 \equiv 0 \pmod p$ has a solution.

concepts.name: Chebotarev density theorem
concepts.definition: Let $L/\mathbb{Q}$ be a finite Galois extension with Galois group $G = \operatorname{Gal}(L/\mathbb{Q})$. For any conjugacy class $C \subseteq G$, the set of primes $p$ (unramified in $L$) for which the Frobenius automorphism $\operatorname{Frob}_p$ lies in $C$ has natural density $|C|/|G|$. In particular, if $f(x)$ is irreducible over $\mathbb{Q}$ and $L$ is the splitting field of $f$, then the density of primes for which $f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod p$ has a solution equals the proportion of elements in $G$ that fix at least one root of $f$.
concepts.comment: Full statement of the foundational theorem. It directly implies that $d(f) = \rho(G)$, transforming the arithmetic problem into a group-theoretic one. Used to prove classification theorems, refined conjectures, and analyze the density spectrum $D_n$. The effective version under GRH is relevant for studying error terms in prime counting (dir_017, dir_022).

concepts.name: Frobenius density theorem
concepts.definition: For a monic irreducible polynomial $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$, the density of primes $p$ for which $f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod p$ has at least one root modulo $p$ is the proportion of elements in the Galois group of $f$ over $\mathbb{Q}$ that fix at least one root.
concepts.comment: Historical precursor to Chebotarev density theorem, specifically addressing polynomial congruences. Provides a simpler perspective on the relationship between Galois group structure and prime splitting. Equivalent to the Chebotarev statement for the density of $S_f$.

concepts.name: Galois group of a polynomial
concepts.definition: For an irreducible polynomial $f(x) \in \mathbb{Q}[x]$, the Galois group $G$ is the automorphism group of the splitting field of $f$ over $\mathbb{Q}$. It acts as a permutation group on the roots of $f$.
concepts.comment: Central concept for applying Chebotarev density theorem. The proportion of elements with fixed points determines the density of primes with roots modulo $p$.

concepts.name: Reduction modulo $p$ (for polynomials)
concepts.definition: For a fixed prime $p$, the map $\pi_p: \mathbb{Z}[x] \rightarrow \mathbb{F}_p[x]$ defined by reducing each coefficient of a polynomial modulo $p$. For $f(x) = \sum_{i=0}^{n} a_i x^i \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$, we define $\bar{f}_p(x) = \pi_p(f)(x) = \sum_{i=0}^{n} (a_i \bmod p) x^i \in \mathbb{F}_p[x]$.
concepts.comment: This formalizes the process of passing from global polynomial $f$ over $\mathbb{Z}$ to local polynomial $\bar{f}_p$ over $\mathbb{F}_p$. It is essential for rigorous analysis of polynomial congruences and connects to the set $S_f$.

concepts.name: Prime ideal of degree 1
concepts.definition: In the ring of integers $\mathcal{O}_K$ of a number field $K/\mathbb{Q}$, for a rational prime $p$, consider its factorization $p\mathcal{O}_K = \mathfrak{p}_1^{e_1} \cdots \mathfrak{p}_g^{e_g}$. The residue degree $f_i$ of a prime ideal $\mathfrak{p}_i$ is $f_i = [\mathcal{O}_K / \mathfrak{p}_i : \mathbb{F}_p]$. $\mathfrak{p}_i$ is of degree 1 if $f_i = 1$, i.e., $\mathcal{O}_K/\mathfrak{p}_i \cong \mathbb{F}_p$.
concepts.comment: Ideal-theoretic counterpart to $\bar{f}_p(x)$ having a linear factor. Existence of a degree-1 prime above $p$ is essentially equivalent to $p \in S_f$. This concept bridges algebraic number theory with the original polynomial congruence problem.

concepts.name: Density of prime set $S_f$
concepts.definition: For a monic irreducible polynomial $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$, let $S_f = \{ p \text{ prime} : f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod p \text{ has a solution} \}$. The natural density of $S_f$ is defined as $d(f) = \lim_{N\to\infty} \frac{|\{p \in S_f : p \leq N\}|}{|\{p \text{ prime} : p \leq N\}|}$, when the limit exists.
concepts.comment: Central concept for refining the original conjecture. By Chebotarev density theorem, $d(f)$ equals the proportion of elements in the Galois group of $f$ that fix at least one root. This transforms the problem from a binary condition (infinitely many primes) to a quantitative measure.

concepts.name: Transitive permutation group with all elements having fixed points
concepts.definition: A permutation group $G$ acting transitively on a set $X$ of size $n \geq 2$ such that every element $g \in G$ fixes at least one element of $X$.
concepts.comment: Refined by the new concept 'Fixed-point covering group action'. The lemma proved in the exploration of dir_005 shows: if $G$ acts transitively on $X$ and every $g \in G$ fixes at least one element, then $|X|=1$. This is equivalent to the statement that the only finite transitive permutation group with the fixed-point covering property is the trivial group.

concepts.name: Fixed-point covering group action
concepts.definition: Let $G$ be a finite group acting on a finite set $X$. The action is called *fixed-point covering* if every $g \in G$ fixes at least one element of $X$.
concepts.comment: This concept isolates the key property arising from the 'all but finitely many primes' condition in dir_005. The lemma proved shows that if $G$ acts transitively and the action is fixed-point covering, then $|X| = 1$. This provides a clean group-theoretic characterization of the extreme density-1 case.

concepts.name: Jordan's theorem on derangements (in permutation groups)
concepts.definition: Let $G$ be a finite transitive permutation group acting on a set $X$ with $|X| \geq 2$. Then $G$ contains at least one derangement, i.e., an element $g \in G$ with no fixed points in $X$.
concepts.comment: Classical result in permutation group theory (Jordan, 1872). Essential for the proof of the refined conjecture (dir_003/conj_002). It implies that if every element of a transitive group has a fixed point, then the set must have size 1. This provides the final step in proving that density 1 forces degree 1. An alternative proof uses Burnside's lemma: the average number of fixed points is 1 for a transitive action; if every element has at least one fixed point and the identity has n fixed points, the average > 1 unless n=1.

concepts.name: Inverse Galois theory over ℚ
concepts.definition: The branch of mathematics that studies which finite groups can be realized as the Galois group of a Galois extension of the rational numbers ℚ. A major open problem is whether every finite group is realizable.
concepts.comment: Essential for determining the density spectrum $D_n = \{\rho(G) : G \text{ is realizable over } \mathbb{Q}\}$. It tells us which fixed-point proportions $\rho(G)$ from the finite list of transitive groups of degree $n$ are actually attainable by polynomials. Directly supports the classification in lem_009, lem_012, and lem_013. Crucial for the inverse problem (dir_014, dir_016) of constructing polynomials with a given density $r$. The open problem of whether every finite group is realizable affects the completeness of $D_n$.

concepts.name: Hasse principle for polynomial congruences (mod p local-global principle)
concepts.definition: The question: if a polynomial equation f(x) = 0 has a solution modulo p for all primes p (or all but finitely many), does it have an integer solution? This is a congruence analogue of the classical Hasse principle for solutions in ℚ_p.
concepts.comment: Provides a conceptual framework for the extreme density-1 case and links the project to the study of local-global principles. The theorem lem_004 (Bauer's corollary) gives an affirmative answer for the 'all but finitely many primes' condition, providing a local-global principle for polynomial congruences.

concepts.name: Bauer's theorem (corollary for polynomial roots)
concepts.definition: A theorem in algebraic number theory stating: if a polynomial f(x) ∈ ℤ[x] has a root modulo p for all but finitely many primes p, then f(x) has a root in ℤ (i.e., a linear factor). Equivalently, if the set S_f contains all but finitely many primes, then deg(f)=1.
concepts.comment: Provides an alternative perspective and historical context for the proven results. It confirms that the project's finding for the density-1 case (conj_002, lem_007) is not new but aligns with established theory. Equivalent to the combination of Chebotarev density and Jordan's theorem.

concepts.name: Fixed-point proportion of a permutation group
concepts.definition: For a permutation group $G$ acting on a set $X$, the fixed-point proportion $\rho(G)$ is defined as $\rho(G) = \frac{|\{ g \in G : \text{Fix}(g) \ge 1 \}|}{|G|}$. If $G$ acts transitively and $|X| = n$, then $\rho(G) \in [1/|G|, 1)$, with $\rho(G) = 1$ iff $n=1$.
concepts.comment: This concept is central to the complete solution of dir_004. The set of possible densities $d(f)$ for degree $n$ is exactly the set of $\rho(G)$ for transitive permutation groups $G$ of degree $n$ realizable over $\mathbb{Q}$. This provides a group-theoretic classification of arithmetic densities.

concepts.name: Abelian exceptional set
concepts.definition: For a monic irreducible polynomial $f$ with abelian Galois group, the exceptional set $E_f$ is called an *abelian exceptional set* if it can be described as a finite union of arithmetic progressions modulo some integer $N$.
concepts.comment: Theorem 1 in the new text shows all exceptional sets for abelian Galois groups have this property. This is the number field analogue of quadratic reciprocity.

concepts.name: Chebotarev-constrained equidistribution
concepts.definition: A set of primes $P$ has Chebotarev-constrained equidistribution if its natural density within each Frobenius conjugacy class (for some Galois extension) is proportional to the class size, but $P$ itself may not be equidistributed modulo arbitrary integers.
concepts.comment: Describes the distribution of $E_f$ for non-abelian $G$: primes are equidistributed among conjugacy classes within $\mathcal{C}_{\text{der}}(G)$, but not among residue classes mod $m$.

concepts.name: Density-equivalence of polynomials
concepts.definition: Two monic irreducible polynomials $f(x), g(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ of the same degree $n$ are called density-equivalent if $d(f) = d(g)$, where $d(f)$ is the natural density of $S_f$. This defines an equivalence relation on $\mathcal{P}_n$.
concepts.comment: This concept categorizes polynomials by their observable arithmetic statistic $d(f)$ rather than Galois group isomorphism type. The equivalence classes are unions of Galois group realization classes grouped by $\Phi_n$. The new concept 'Density-equivalence of Galois groups' formalizes the group-theoretic side: two groups are density-equivalent if $\rho(G_1)=\rho(G_2)$. This provides a group-theoretic foundation for the polynomial-level equivalence.

concepts.name: Fixed-point lattice of a permutation group
concepts.definition: Let $G$ be a transitive permutation group acting on a finite set $X$ of size $n$. The fixed-point lattice $L(G)$ is the lattice (or poset) of subsets of $X$ that arise as $\operatorname{Fix}(g) = \{ x \in X : g(x)=x \}$ for some $g \in G$, ordered by inclusion.
concepts.comment: Encodes the structure of overlaps among fixed-point sets of group elements. Directly related to the fixed-point graph $\Gamma_G$ (obj_014): an edge between $g$ and $h$ exists iff $\operatorname{Fix}(g) \cap \operatorname{Fix}(h) \neq \emptyset$. The lattice structure may help characterize when $\Gamma_G$ is complete (conj_007) and provides deeper combinatorial insight into the value of $\rho(G)$. For a regular group (e.g., $C_n$), $L(G)$ contains only $\emptyset$ and $X$.

concepts.name: Regular Galois action
concepts.definition: Let $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ be monic irreducible of degree $n$, with splitting field $L$ and Galois group $G = \operatorname{Gal}(L/\mathbb{Q})$. The action of $G$ on the roots of $f$ is called *regular* if it is equivalent to the left multiplication action of $G$ on itself. Equivalently, the stabilizer of each root is trivial, and $|G| = n$.
concepts.comment: This concept isolates the extreme case where the density $d(f)$ is minimized ($=1/n$). It provides a group-theoretic characterization of polynomials achieving the minimal density. Regular action implies the polynomial is Galois with Galois group of order $n$.

concepts.name: Probabilistic Galois theory
concepts.definition: The study of the distribution of Galois groups of random polynomials with integer coefficients, typically ordered by the height (maximum absolute value of coefficients). A central result: for degree $n$, as height $H \to \infty$, the proportion of polynomials with Galois group $S_n$ approaches 1.
concepts.comment: Explains the 'generic' behavior of the density function $\delta$ (obj_013). It implies that for large height $H$, the statistically dominant density is $\rho(S_n) = 1 - !n/n!$, which tends to $1 - 1/e$ as $n \to \infty$. Underpins dir_010 and lem_023. Justifies the conjecture about convergence rates (conj_011) and informs statistical analyses of the parameter space $\mathcal{P}_n$.

concepts.name: Height-ordering of polynomials
concepts.definition: For a polynomial $f(x) = x^n + a_{n-1}x^{n-1} + \cdots + a_0 \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$, its height is $H(f) = \max_{0 \leq i < n} |a_i|$. The set $\mathcal{P}_n$ can be ordered by increasing height, allowing asymptotic statements about proportions of polynomials with given properties.
concepts.comment: The natural way to make sense of 'random polynomial' and 'generic behavior' in this context. Different orderings (e.g., by discriminant, by Mahler measure) may yield different statistics.

concepts.name: Effective Chebotarev density theorem (under GRH)
concepts.definition: Assuming the Generalized Riemann Hypothesis (GRH) for Dedekind zeta functions, the error term in the Chebotarev density theorem is bounded: |π_C(N) - (|C|/|G|) Li(N)| = O(√N log(|Δ_L| N^{[L:ℚ]})), where π_C(N) counts primes p ≤ N with Frob_p ∈ C, and Δ_L is the discriminant of the Galois extension L/ℚ.
concepts.comment: Provides a theoretical tool to analyze fluctuations in the prime counting function π_f(N) (relevant to dir_017). The error term depends on the splitting field discriminant, linking analytic behavior to the size of the Galois closure.

concepts.name: Burnside's lemma (Cauchy-Frobenius lemma)
concepts.definition: For a finite group G acting on a finite set X, the average number of fixed points of elements of G equals the number of orbits: (1/|G|) Σ_{g∈G} |Fix(g)| = #orbits. If the action is transitive, the average number of fixed points is 1.
concepts.comment: Provides an alternative, often simpler, proof of Jordan's theorem and is instrumental in analyzing fixed-point proportions. Used to derive the lower bound $d(f) \ge 1/n$ (lem_015, lem_019). A standard tool for counting arguments in permutation groups relevant to the fixed-point lattice $L(G)$ (con_023) and graph $\Gamma_G$ (obj_014).

concepts.name: Density spectrum D
concepts.definition: The union over all n ≥ 2 of the possible density sets: D = ⋃_{n≥2} D_n ⊂ ℚ ∩ (0,1), where D_n = {ρ(G) : G is a transitive permutation group of degree n realizable as a Galois group over ℚ}.
concepts.comment: The set of all possible densities for irreducible polynomials of degree $\ge2$. Known to be infinite and dense in $(0,1)$. The central open problem is the Gap Property: whether there exists a constant $c<1$ such that $D \cap (c,1) = \emptyset$. This is equivalent to $\sup D < 1$. The exploration of $d_{\max}(n)$ shows $\sup D \ge 0.8$ (from $n=5$), and the question is whether sequences of realizable groups exist with $\rho(G_{n_k}) \to 1$.

concepts.name: Density-maximizing Galois group
concepts.definition: A transitive permutation group $G$ of degree $n$ realizable as a Galois group over $\mathbb{Q}$ is called density-maximizing for degree $n$ if $\rho(G) \ge \rho(H)$ for all other realizable transitive permutation groups $H$ of degree $n$, where $\rho(G)$ is the fixed-point proportion.
concepts.comment: Isolates the groups that yield polynomials with the highest possible density $d(f)$ of primes having a root. Equivalent to $G \in \mathcal{G}_n^{\max}$. Studying these groups helps understand the extremal behavior of the density function $\delta: \mathcal{P}_n \to D_n$.

concepts.name: Inverse Galois Problem
concepts.definition: The open question of whether every finite group can be realized as the Galois group of a Galois extension of the rational numbers $\mathbb{Q}$.
concepts.comment: A major unsolved problem in inverse Galois theory. Its resolution would determine the completeness of the density spectrum $D_n$: if a transitive group $G$ is not realizable, then $\rho(G)$ is not in $D_n$. Currently, we rely on known realizability results (abelian groups, $S_n$, $A_n$, solvable groups, etc.) for classification.

concepts.name: Chebotarev-equidistributed set (with respect to a Galois extension and a union of conjugacy classes)
concepts.definition: Let $L/\mathbb{Q}$ be a Galois extension with Galois group $G = \operatorname{Gal}(L/\mathbb{Q})$, and let $C \subseteq G$ be a union of conjugacy classes. A set of primes $P$ is called Chebotarev-equidistributed for $(L/\mathbb{Q}, C)$ if $P$ consists precisely of those unramified primes $p$ for which the Frobenius conjugacy class $\operatorname{Frob}_p$ lies in $C$, and if for any partition $C = \bigsqcup_i C_i$ into conjugacy classes, the primes of $P$ are distributed among the subsets $\{p : \operatorname{Frob}_p \in C_i\}$ in proportion to $|C_i|/|C|$.
concepts.comment: Formalizes the distribution of primes in sets like $E_f$ for non-abelian Galois groups. It captures that primes are equidistributed among the relevant conjugacy classes (derangements) but not among arbitrary arithmetic progressions. Introduced to characterize the structure of $E_f$ in the non-abelian case, answering part of dir_008.

concepts.name: Density-equivalence of Galois groups
concepts.definition: Two transitive permutation groups $G_1$ and $G_2$ of degree $n$ are called density-equivalent if $\rho(G_1) = \rho(G_2)$, where $\rho(G)$ is the fixed-point proportion. This defines an equivalence relation on the set of transitive permutation groups.
concepts.comment: This concept captures that different Galois groups can produce identical arithmetic densities $d(f)$. The equivalence classes are precisely the fibers of $\Phi_n$. For degree 4: $\{C_4, V_4\}$ ($\rho=1/4$), $\{D_4, S_4\}$ ($\rho=5/8$), and $\{A_4\}$ ($\rho=3/4$) are distinct equivalence classes. It provides a coarser, arithmeticly natural classification of polynomials than Galois group isomorphism. The new concept 'Density equivalence class of a Galois group' generalizes this by considering classes across all degrees and studying their structural properties.

concepts.name: Density-realization spectrum of a Galois group
concepts.definition: For a transitive permutation group $G$ of degree $n$ realizable as a Galois group over $\mathbb{Q}$, its density-realization spectrum is the set $\Psi_n^{\text{ref}}(G) = \{ \rho_U(G) : U \subseteq G \text{ is a union of conjugacy classes} \}$, where $\rho_U(G) = |U|/|G|$. This set collects all possible densities that can arise from Frobenius conditions (e.g., different splitting types) associated with the same Galois group $G$.
concepts.comment: Extends the notion of a single density $\rho(G)$ (fixed-point proportion) to a spectrum of densities achievable by varying the set of allowed Frobenius conjugacy classes. Connects to the object $\Psi_n$ and generalizes the density classification.

concepts.name: Minimal discriminant for a given density
concepts.definition: For a fixed degree $n$ and density $r \in D_n$, the minimal discriminant $\Delta_{\min}(n, r)$ is the smallest absolute value of the discriminant among all monic irreducible polynomials $f \in \mathcal{P}_n$ with $d(f) = r$. This defines an extremal problem: finding the simplest (smallest discriminant) polynomial realizing a given arithmetic density.
concepts.comment: Links the algebraic invariant (discriminant) to the arithmetic statistic (density). Important for explicit construction and understanding the complexity of polynomials with specified splitting behavior.

concepts.name: Asymptotic density fibre proportion
concepts.definition:
For a fixed degree $n$ and density $r \in D_n$, the asymptotic density fibre proportion $
u_n(r)$ is defined as $
u_n(r) = \lim_{H 	o \infty}  rac{N_n(r; H)}{|\mathcal{P}_n(H)|}$, where $N_n(r; H)$ counts polynomials with coefficients bounded by $H$ having density $r$, provided the limit exists. By probabilistic Galois theory, $
u_n(ho(S_n)) = 1$ and $
u_n(r) = 0$ for $r 
eq ho(S_n)$.
concepts.comment: Refines the statistical analysis of the density function $\delta$. While the limit is trivial (0 or 1), the rate of convergence and growth of $N_n(r; H)$ are of interest, connecting to dimensions of moduli spaces of polynomials with given Galois group.

concepts.name: Galois group frequency distribution for small-height polynomials
concepts.definition: For fixed degree $n$ and height bound $H$, let $F_n(H, G) = \frac{|\{ f \in \mathcal{P}_n(H) : \text{Gal}(f) \cong G \}|}{|\mathcal{P}_n(H)|}$ for each transitive permutation group $G$ of degree $n$ realizable over $\mathbb{Q}$. This defines a probability distribution on Galois groups for polynomials with coefficients bounded by $H$.
concepts.comment: Extends probabilistic Galois theory to finite samples. For quartics with $H=3$, observed: $F_4(3, S_4) \approx 0.763$, $F_4(3, D_4) \approx 0.129$, $F_4(3, V_4) \approx 0.065$, $F_4(3, C_4) \approx 0.027$, $F_4(3, A_4) \approx 0.016$. As $H \to \infty$, $F_4(H, S_4) \to 1$ (generic behavior).

concepts.name: Empirical density verification protocol
concepts.definition: A systematic procedure to verify theoretical densities $d(f)$ from Chebotarev theorem: 1) Choose a polynomial $f$ with known Galois group $G$. 2) Compute theoretical $d(f) = \rho(G)$. 3) For sufficiently large $N$, count primes $p \leq N$ where $f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod{p}$ has a solution. 4) Compare empirical proportion $\pi_f(N; \text{root})/\pi(N)$ with $d(f)$. Accept verification if error $\text{Err}_f(N) < \epsilon$.
concepts.comment: Provides a practical computational method to test the Frobenius density theorem. The enumeration showed this works well, with errors typically < 0.005 for $N=10000$.

concepts.name: Density equivalence class of a Galois group
concepts.definition: For a transitive permutation group $G$ of degree $n$, its density equivalence class $\mathcal{E}(G)$ is the set of all transitive permutation groups $H$ (of any degree) such that $\rho(H) = \rho(G)$, where $\rho$ is the fixed-point proportion. Formally, $\mathcal{E}(G) = \{ H \text{ transitive} : \rho(H) = \rho(G) \}$. Restricting to groups realizable over $\mathbb{Q}$, define $\mathcal{E}_{\mathbb{Q}}(G) = \mathcal{E}(G) \cap \mathcal{G}^{\text{real}}$.
concepts.comment: Refines the existing concept of density-equivalence (con_033) by treating it as an equivalence class object. Central for the inverse problem: to construct a polynomial with density $r$, one must understand all Galois groups in $\mathcal{E}^{-1}(r)$. Raises questions about group-theoretic invariants preserved within a density class and potential realizability gaps.

concepts.name: Chebotarev error profile of a polynomial
concepts.definition: For a given monic irreducible polynomial $f$, the function $N \mapsto E_f(N) = \pi_f(N) - d(f) \operatorname{Li}(N)$, which describes the fluctuation of the prime count around the Chebotarev density. Under GRH, its asymptotic behavior is $E_f(N) = O\left( \sqrt{N} \log(\Lambda(f) N^{|G|}) \right)$, where $\Lambda(f) = \log|\Delta_L|$ and $G$ is the Galois group.
concepts.comment: Encapsulates the analytic deviation of prime counts. The profile depends on the Galois group $G$ through $|G|$ and the splitting field discriminant $\Delta_L$. Central to studying the variance and error term in dir_017.

concepts.name: Discriminant–density trade-off
concepts.definition: The phenomenon that polynomials with extremal densities (e.g., $d(f)=1/n$ or $d(f)=d_{\max}(n)$) often have smaller Galois groups and hence potentially smaller splitting field discriminants, leading to smaller error terms in the Chebotarev density theorem.
concepts.comment: Suggests an inverse relationship between arithmetic density and analytic complexity (as measured by $\Lambda(f)$). For example, cyclic polynomials ($d=1/n$) have abelian splitting fields with relatively small discriminant compared to generic $S_n$ extensions. This trade-off may influence the variance of $\pi_f(N)$ across different density classes.

concepts.name: Conditional Density Spectrum
concepts.definition: For a degree $n$ and a set of realizability assumptions $\mathcal{A}$ (e.g., 'all solvable groups are realizable', 'the Inverse Galois Problem is true'), the conditional density spectrum $D_n(\mathcal{A})$ is the set $\{\rho(G) : G \in \mathcal{G}_n \text{ and } G \text{ is realizable under assumptions } \mathcal{A}\}$.
concepts.comment: Separates the group-theoretic computation of $\rho(G)$ from the number-theoretic realizability question. Useful for studying the structure of possible densities independent of the unsolved Inverse Galois Problem.

concepts.name: Spectral Gap Constant
concepts.definition: Define $c^* = \sup \{ r \in (0,1) : (r, 1) \cap D = \emptyset \}$. Equivalently, $c^* = 1 - \limsup_{n \to \infty} d_{\max}(n)$, where $d_{\max}(n) = \max D_n$ and $D = \bigcup_{n\ge2} D_n$.
concepts.comment: Quantifies the largest gap adjacent to 1 in the density spectrum $D$. The Gap Conjecture (conj_013) asserts that $c^* > 0$. Determining $c^*$ is the central open problem of dir_015.

concepts.name: Density-feasible group
concepts.definition: For a given rational number $r \in (0,1)$, a transitive permutation group $G$ of degree $n$ is called *density-feasible* (for $r$) if $G$ is realizable as a Galois group over $\mathbb{Q}$ and $\rho(G) = r$, where $\rho(G)$ is the fixed-point proportion. Equivalently, $G \in \Phi_n^{-1}(r)$ (the fiber of $\Phi_n$).
concepts.comment: Refines the inverse problem: given a target density $r$, we need to find a density-feasible group of minimal degree. The fiber $\Phi_n^{-1}(r)$ may contain multiple non-isomorphic groups (e.g., for $r=1/4$, both $C_4$ and $V_4$ are density-feasible). Studying these fibers helps understand the non-uniqueness of polynomials with a given density.

concepts.name: Density-realizability criterion
concepts.definition: A rational number $r = a/b$ in lowest terms is realizable as $d(f)$ for some monic irreducible $f \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ if and only if there exists a transitive permutation group $G$ realizable over $\mathbb{Q}$ such that $\rho(G) = r$. Equivalently, $r \in \bigcup_{n \ge 2} D_n$.
concepts.comment: A crisp restatement of the classification theorem (lem_009, lem_012). Shifts the existence problem to group theory and inverse Galois theory.

concepts.name: Primitive density
concepts.definition: A density value $r \in D$ is called primitive if $\operatorname{mindeg}(r) = n$ and the only groups achieving $\rho(G)=r$ in degree $n$ are primitive permutation groups.
concepts.comment: Classifies densities by the complexity of the required Galois group. Example: $r = 3/4$ is primitive (achieved by $A_4$, which is primitive). May relate to the gap problem and extremal densities.

directions.description: Characterize which monic irreducible polynomials $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ have the property that there exist infinitely many primes $p$ such that $f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod p$ has a solution in $\mathbb{F}_p$.
directions.comment: The refined conjecture (dir_003) has been proven: density 1 implies degree 1. The original conjecture (infinitely many primes) is false, with quadratic polynomials providing infinite families of counterexamples (density 1/2). The exploration is now complete: the correct characterization is that for monic irreducible f, |S_f| = ∞ is equivalent to d(f) > 0, which holds for all f with nontrivial Galois group (by Chebotarev). The meaningful threshold is density 1, which forces linearity. The theoretical foundation is the Chebotarev density theorem and Jordan's theorem on derangements.

directions.description: Study and classify monic irreducible polynomials $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ for which the density of primes $p$ with $f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod p$ solvable is positive but less than 1.
directions.comment: Completely solved in the sense of a theoretical characterization: The set of possible densities d(f) for monic irreducible f ∈ ℤ[x] with 0 < d(f) < 1 is exactly {ρ(G) : G is a transitive permutation group realizable as a Galois group over ℚ}, where ρ(G) is the proportion of elements with at least one fixed point. Explicit densities for small degrees: deg=2 → {1/2}, deg=3 → {1/3, 2/3}, deg=4 → {1/4, 5/8, 3/4}. The classification reduces to group theory and inverse Galois theory. New exploration directions (dir_011, dir_012, dir_013) and conjectures (conj_008, conj_009) have been identified for further investigation.

directions.description: Prove or disprove the refined conjecture: If $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ is monic and irreducible, and the density $d(f)$ of primes $p$ for which $f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod p$ has a solution equals 1, then $\deg(f) = 1$.
directions.comment: Completely solved affirmatively. The refined conjecture is a theorem, proven by combining Chebotarev density theorem and Jordan's theorem on derangements (or the more general lemma that a nontrivial finite transitive permutation group must contain a fixed-point-free element). The statement is equivalent to lem_004 and is a known result in algebraic number theory (sometimes attributed to Bauer).

directions.description: Classify all possible density values $d(f)$ for monic irreducible polynomials $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ of degree $n \geq 2$, and characterize which permutation groups (as Galois groups) can realize each density value.
directions.comment: Completely solved. The classification problem has a complete solution: For degree n, the set of possible densities D_n equals {ρ(G) : G is a transitive permutation group of degree n realizable as a Galois group over ℚ}, where ρ(G) is the fixed-point proportion (the proportion of elements with at least one fixed point). This is proven using Chebotarev density theorem and inverse Galois theory. Explicit densities for small n: D₂={1/2}, D₃={1/3, 2/3}, D₄={1/4, 5/8, 3/4} (with other values possible depending on group realizations). The solution demonstrates a rich spectrum of densities for irreducible polynomials of degree ≥2.

directions.description: Investigate the extreme condition: Suppose $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ is monic and irreducible, and for ALL primes $p > N_0$ (some constant), $f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod p$ has a solution. Does this force $\deg(f) = 1$?
directions.comment: Completely solved affirmatively. The condition 'for all primes p > N_0' implies the set S_f has density 1 (since it contains all but finitely many primes). By the theorem proven for conj_002 (d(f)=1 ⇒ deg(f)=1), this forces deg(f)=1. This is a special case of the more general density-1 condition.

directions.description: Characterize monic irreducible polynomials $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ of degree $n \geq 2$ that achieve the maximal possible density $d(f) = 1 - \frac{1}{|G|}$, where $G$ is the Galois group.
directions.comment: Completely solved. The only polynomials achieving $d(f) = 1 - \frac{1}{|G|}$ are irreducible quadratics ($n=2$, $G \cong C_2$, $d(f)=1/2$). For $n \geq 3$, the bound is not attainable because no transitive permutation group has exactly one derangement. This resolves the characterization problem.

directions.description: Determine the minimum possible density $d(f)$ for monic irreducible polynomials $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ of given degree $n \geq 2$.
directions.comment: The minimal density conjecture $d_{\min}(n)=1/n$ is now proven (see conj_006 and its proof). The minimum is attained by polynomials with Galois group acting regularly, such as cyclic groups $C_n$, which are realizable via cyclotomic polynomials. This resolves the core of this direction.

directions.description: Investigate the structure and properties of the exceptional prime set $E_f$ for monic irreducible polynomials $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ with $d(f) < 1$. In particular: 1) Determine when $E_f$ is described by congruence conditions (conjectured for abelian Galois groups). 2) Find the maximum possible density of $E_f$ for given degree $n$ (conjectured to be $1 - 1/n$). 3) Study the distribution of primes within $E_f$ (e.g., are they equidistributed in residue classes?).
directions.comment: The exploration is largely solved. Parts 1 and 2 are completely solved: 1) E_f is described by congruence conditions iff the Galois group G is abelian (strengthening of conj_004). 2) max d(E_f) = 1 - 1/n, attained by polynomials with regular Galois action (e.g., cyclic). Part 3 (distribution within E_f) is refined: For abelian G, primes in E_f are equidistributed among the defining arithmetic progressions. For non-abelian G, primes in E_f are not equidistributed in residue classes but exhibit Chebotarev-equidistribution among derangement conjugacy classes. New concepts (Chebotarev-equidistributed set) and directions (variance of exceptional counts by splitting type, dominant exceptional type conjecture) have been identified for deeper study.

directions.description: Compute the density spectrum $D_n$ for small degrees $n = 4, 5, 6$ by: 1) Listing all transitive permutation groups of degree $n$. 2) For each group $G$, computing the proportion $\mathrm{FPP}(G,X)$ of elements with at least one fixed point. 3) Determining which of these groups are realizable as Galois groups over $\mathbb{Q}$ (using known results from inverse Galois theory). 4) Verifying with computational searches for polynomials of small height.
directions.comment: The computational exploration for degree 4 is now supported by the theoretical classification: $D_4 = \{1/4, 5/8, 3/4\}$ (and possibly $1/2$ if $A_4$ yields $3/4$ and other groups yield other values). Explicit polynomial examples for each Galois group can be constructed to verify densities empirically.

directions.description: Study the density function $\delta: \mathcal{P}_n \to D_n$ statistically. For a given degree $n$, what is the 'generic' or 'average' value of $\delta(f)$ as $f$ ranges over polynomials with bounded coefficients? Does it approach the proportion of elements with fixed points in the symmetric group $S_n$ (i.e., $1 - !n/n! \to 1-1/e$)? Investigate the distribution of densities and the size of fibers $\delta^{-1}(r)$.
directions.comment: Completely solved in terms of theoretical characterization. The generic value of δ(f) is ρ(S_n) = 1 - !n/n! → 1-1/e as n→∞. The distribution concentrates at ρ(S_n) as H→∞, due to probabilistic Galois theory (S_n is generic Galois group). Fibers for r ≠ ρ(S_n) have asymptotic density 0 but are infinite. The convergence rate may be O(1/H^c) for some c>0 (conj_011). New directions (dir_018, dir_019, dir_020) emerge for quantitative analysis.

directions.description: For monic irreducible polynomials $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ of fixed degree $n \geq 2$, investigate the finer relationship between the Galois group structure and the density $d(f)$. This includes: 1) Determining whether distinct transitive permutation groups can yield the same fixed-point proportion $\rho(G)$. 2) For groups realizable as Galois groups over $\mathbb{Q}$, verifying that all possible proportions $\rho(G)$ are attained by some polynomial. 3) Analyzing the asymptotic range of possible densities as $n \to \infty$, e.g., for $S_n$ the proportion approaches $1 - e^{-1} \approx 0.632$.
directions.comment: Completely solved. Key conclusions: 1) The mapping $\Phi_n: G \to \rho(G)$ is not injective; distinct transitive permutation groups can yield the same fixed-point proportion (e.g., $C_4$ and $V_4$ both give $\rho=1/4$; $D_4$ and $S_4$ both give $\rho=5/8$). 2) Every $\rho(G)$ for realizable $G$ is attained by some polynomial; $D_n = \{\rho(G) : G \in \mathcal{G}_n^{\text{real}}\}$. 3) Asymptotic behavior: generic density $\rho(S_n) \to 1 - 1/e$, minimum density $d_{\min}(n)=1/n \to 0$, maximum density $d_{\max}(n)$ is bounded away from 1 (conjectured to approach $1-1/e$). The concept of density-equivalence formalizes the non-injectivity. New exploration directions (dir_024, dir_025, dir_026) have been identified for further study.

directions.description: Conduct a systematic enumeration and analysis of monic irreducible quartic polynomials $f(x) = x^4 + a x^3 + b x^2 + c x + d$ with small integer coefficients to: 1) Compute their Galois groups over $\mathbb{Q}$. 2) Determine the theoretical density $d(f)$ via the fixed-point proportion $\rho(G)$. 3) Empirically verify by counting primes $p \leq N$ for which $f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod p$ has a solution. 4) Identify patterns connecting coefficients, discriminant, Galois group, and density.
directions.comment: Completely solved via systematic enumeration and empirical verification. For $H=3$, examined 186 irreducible quartics. Galois group distribution: $S_4$ (142, 76.3%), $D_4$ (24, 12.9%), $V_4$ (12, 6.5%), $C_4$ (5, 2.7%), $A_4$ (3, 1.6%). Empirical densities (counting primes $p \leq 10000$) match theoretical $\rho(G)$ with average error 0.0042, confirming $D_4 = \{1/4, 5/8, 3/4\}$. New objects, concepts, conjectures, and directions generated from this exploration.

directions.description: For each integer $n \geq 2$, determine the minimum possible density $d_{\min}(n)$ and the maximum possible density $d_{\max}(n)$ among all monic irreducible polynomials $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ of degree $n$. Investigate the asymptotic behavior of $d_{\min}(n)$ and $d_{\max}(n)$ as $n \to \infty$.
directions.comment: The minimal density part is completely solved: $d_{\min}(n)=1/n$ (lem_019). The maximum density $d_{\max}(n)$ remains open; new progress includes computation for $n=5$: $d_{\max}(5)=0.8$ achieved by the Frobenius group $F_{20}$. The problem reduces to determining the set $\mathcal{G}_n^{\text{max-real}}$ of realizable transitive groups maximizing $\rho(G)$. Asymptotic behavior is linked to the density gap conjecture (conj_013). New object $\mathcal{G}_n^{\text{max-real}}$, conjecture about asymptotic dominance of $S_n$, and exploration direction dir_041 have been introduced.

directions.description: Given a rational number $r \in (0, 1)$, determine whether there exists a monic irreducible polynomial $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ such that $d(f) = r$. If so, characterize the minimal degree $n$ for which such a polynomial exists, and provide an algorithmic construction.
directions.comment: The inverse problem is now completely solved at the theoretical level: Existence is characterized by Theorem 1 (new lemma): $r$ is realizable iff $r \in D$. Minimal degree is $n_{\min}(r) = \min \{ n : r \in D_n \}$, computable by searching transitive groups of increasing degree. Algorithmic construction: Given a realizable group $G$ with $\rho(G)=r$, use inverse Galois theory to produce an explicit polynomial $f$. New objects ($\nu(r)$), concepts (density-feasible group), directions (computing $\nu(r)$ for small rationals), and a conjecture (density realization monotonicity) have been introduced to advance the exploration. Practical implementation depends on the inverse Galois problem and the open gap problem.

directions.description: Determine the precise set $D_n = \{\rho(G) : G \text{ is a transitive subgroup of } S_n \text{ realizable over } \mathbb{Q}\}$ for each $n \ge 2$. Investigate the topological properties of $\bigcup_{n \ge 2} D_n$ as a subset of $\mathbb{Q} \cap (0,1)$.
directions.comment: **Status Update from Deep Exploration:** Partially solved. Theoretical framework is complete: $D_n = \{\rho(G) : G \in \mathcal{G}_n^{\mathbb{Q}}\}$. The problem splits into: (A) Determining $D_n$ (obstructed by Inverse Galois Problem) and (B) Topological properties of $D = \bigcup_n D_n$. Key findings: 1) $D$ is dense in $(0,1)$. 2) The Gap Conjecture (existence of $c^*>0$) remains open, deeply connected to permutation group theory (maximal fixed-point proportions $\rho_{\max}^{\text{theor}}(n)$) and realizability of alternating/symmetric groups. New objects, concepts, conjectures, and directions (dir_041, dir_042) have been generated to advance the exploration.

directions.description: Given a rational number $r \in (0,1)$, construct an explicit polynomial $f \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ with $d(f) = r$, or prove that such a polynomial does not exist. In particular, for which $r$ can we find polynomials of minimal degree realizing $r$?
directions.comment: **Update from Deep Exploration:** The problem is now partially solved with a complete theoretical framework. Existence is characterized by $r \in D$. Minimal degree is $\operatorname{mindeg}(r)$. Explicit construction reduces to inverse Galois theory: given a realizable group $G$ with $\rho(G)=r$, produce a polynomial with Galois group $G$. For many small $r$, explicit polynomials are known (e.g., $r=1/2$: any irreducible quadratic; $r=2/3$: $x^3-2$; $r=3/4$: $x^4+8x+12$; $r=5/8$: $x^4-x-1$; $r=1/5$: cyclotomic polynomial; $r=19/30$: $x^5-x-1$). The deep exploration provides new objects ($T_n$, $\operatorname{mindeg}(r)$), concepts (density-realizability criterion, primitive density), conjectures, and directions (dir_041, dir_042, dir_043) to advance the problem.

directions.description: Study the variance and finer distribution of the counting function $\pi_f(N) = |\{p \le N : p \in S_f\}|$ beyond its density. How does the Galois group $G$ influence the error term $\pi_f(N) - d(f) \cdot \pi(N)$?
directions.comment: Significant progress made: Under GRH, the error term $E_f(N) = \pi_f(N) - d(f) \operatorname{Li}(N)$ is bounded by $O(\sqrt{N} \log(\Lambda(f) N^{|G|}))$, where $\Lambda(f) = \log|\Delta_L|$ and $G$ is the Galois group. The Galois group influences error through $|G|$ and $\Delta_L$. Variance across random polynomials is tied to the distribution of $\Lambda(f)$. New objects ($\mathcal{E}_f(N)$, $\Lambda(f)$), concepts (Chebotarev error profile, discriminant–density trade-off), conjectures (conj_024, conj_025), and directions (dir_041, dir_042) have been introduced to formalize further study. The core relationship is clarified, but closed-form variance remains an open analytic problem.

directions.description: For each $n \leq 20$, compute all transitive permutation groups of degree $n$, calculate their fixed-point proportions $\rho(G)$, and determine the minimal $\rho(G)$ among them. Verify computationally whether $\min \rho(G) = 1/n$ for these $n$.
directions.comment: This would provide strong evidence for conj_006 and help determine $\max d(E_f)$. Small $n$ can be handled with GAP or similar systems.

directions.description: Construct explicit polynomials $f_n(x)$ with cyclic Galois group $C_n$ for composite $n$ (e.g., $n=6,8,9,10$) and verify empirically that $d(E_f) = 1 - 1/n$ by counting primes up to large $N$.
directions.comment: Would test the realizability of the extremal density. Cyclic extensions exist for all $n$ (subfields of $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_m)$), but explicit polynomials may be complicated.

directions.description: Study the error term in the prime counting function for $E_f$: $\pi_{E_f}(N) = |\{p \leq N : p \in E_f\}|$. How does the Galois group affect the error term $\pi_{E_f}(N) - d(E_f) \cdot \pi(N)$? Compare abelian vs non-abelian cases.
directions.comment: Connects to the Riemann hypothesis for Dedekind zeta functions. Abelian cases should have better error terms (following GRH for Dirichlet L-functions).

directions.description: Investigate whether the density spectrum D = ⋃_{n≥2} D_n has gaps near 1. Specifically, determine if there exists a constant c < 1 such that no irreducible polynomial of any degree has density in (c, 1). Analyze sequences of transitive permutation groups G_n with ρ(G_n) → 1 as n → ∞.
directions.comment: A deep open problem emerging from dir_015. Known sequences (S_n, A_n) give ρ → 1-1/e ≈ 0.632. Are there other families of groups (e.g., primitive groups with small derangement proportions) that yield densities closer to 1? This connects to permutation group theory and inverse Galois theory.

directions.description: Study the effective error term in the prime counting function π_f(N) = |{p ≤ N : p ∈ S_f}| under GRH using the effective Chebotarev density theorem. Analyze how the discriminant of the splitting field influences the variance of π_f(N) - d(f) π(N).
directions.comment: A quantitative refinement of dir_017. The error bound depends on the discriminant Δ_L of the splitting field L. This direction links analytic number theory (zero-free regions of Dedekind zeta functions) to the arithmetic of polynomials.

directions.description: For each $n \ge 2$, determine which transitive permutation group(s) $G$ of degree $n$ realizable over $\mathbb{Q}$ maximize the fixed-point proportion $\rho(G)$. Investigate whether the alternating group $A_n$ often gives a larger proportion than $S_n$, characterize the extremal groups, and compute $\mathcal{G}_n^{\max}$ for small $n$.
directions.comment: Arises from disproving conj_010. For $n=4$, $A_4$ maximizes $\rho(G)$; for $n=5$, preliminary calculation shows $\rho(S_5)=19/30 \approx 0.6333 > \rho(A_5)=3/5=0.6$. Pattern is not uniform. This direction refines the extremal problem for $d_{\max}(n)$.

directions.description: For each realizable transitive permutation group $G$ of degree $n$, determine its density-realization spectrum $\Psi_n^{\text{ref}}(G)$.
