Investigate properties such as: minimal and maximal elements, whether the spectrum is always an interval of rational numbers, and how it relates to the lattice of subgroups of $G$. Explore whether the union $\bigcup_{G \in \mathcal{G}_n^{\text{real}}} \Psi_n^{\text{ref}}(G)$ equals the set of all possible densities for any Frobenius condition definable by a degree-$n$ polynomial.
directions.comment: This direction is now enriched with a detailed motivation and potential proof methods from the new text. A special case study for $G = S_4$ is suggested to explicitly compute the density-realization spectrum.

directions.description: For each $n \ge 2$ and $r \in D_n$, compute or bound the minimal discriminant $\Delta_{\min}(n, r)$. Investigate relationships: Does $\Delta_{\min}(n, r)$ increase with $r$? Is it always realized by a polynomial with the smallest possible Galois group order for that density? For $r=1/n$, is the minimizer given by a cyclotomic polynomial?
directions.comment: This direction is now enriched with a detailed motivation and potential proof methods from the new text. A special case study for $n=4$, $r=3/4$ (density achieved by $A_4$ quartics) is suggested to search for minimal discriminant.

directions.description: Study the growth of $N_n(r; H)$ as $H \to \infty$ for $r \in D_n \setminus \{\rho(S_n)\}$. Determine asymptotic formulas $N_n(r; H) \sim c_{n,r} H^{n - \alpha_{n,r}}$ and compute the exponents $\alpha_{n,r}$. Relate $\alpha_{n,r}$ to the dimension of the moduli space of polynomials with Galois group $G$ (where $\rho(G)=r$). Investigate whether $\alpha_{n,r}$ decreases as $r$ approaches $\rho(S_n)$.
directions.comment: This direction is now enriched with a detailed motivation and potential proof methods from the new text. A special case study for $n=4$, $r=1/4$ is suggested to estimate the growth exponent $\alpha_{4,1/4}$.

directions.description: For transitive permutation groups $G$, compute the automorphism group $\operatorname{Aut}(L(G))$ of the fixed-point lattice. Investigate: Is $\operatorname{Aut}(L(G))$ isomorphic to the normalizer of $G$ in $S_n$ modulo the center? Does the lattice isomorphism type $L(G)$ determine the permutation group $G$ up to isomorphism when $\rho(G)$ and $|G|$ are fixed?
directions.comment: This direction is now enriched with a detailed motivation and potential proof methods from the new text. A special case study for degree 4 groups is suggested to analyze the fixed-point graph and lattice.

directions.description: For abelian polynomials $f$ of degree $n$, study the minimal modulus $N_f^{\min}$ of the exceptional set $E_f$. Determine all possible values of $N_f^{\min}$ for given $n$, and relate it to the discriminant $\Delta_f$ and the conductor of the cyclotomic field. Is the map $f \mapsto N_f^{\min}$ finite-to-one on abelian $\mathcal{P}_n$?
directions.comment: Refines the structure of abelian exceptional sets (dir_008). The minimal modulus is a canonical invariant that measures the complexity of the periodic description.

directions.description: Determine the behavior of the density gap function $\gamma(\epsilon)$. Is $\gamma(\epsilon)$ finite for all $\epsilon > 0$ (Gap Conjecture)? If not, characterize its growth rate as $\epsilon \to 0$ (e.g., polynomial, exponential). Relate to the existence of transitive permutation groups of large degree with few derangements.
directions.comment: This direction is now enriched with a detailed motivation and potential proof methods from the new text. A special case study to compute $\gamma(\epsilon)$ for small $\epsilon$ using transitive groups up to degree 30 is suggested.

directions.description: Construct explicit monic irreducible polynomials $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ of composite degree $n$ that achieve the minimal density $d(f) = 1/n$. Verify empirically by prime counting and analyze their discriminants and conductors.
directions.comment: Theoretical existence is guaranteed by lem_019 (regular Galois action, e.g., cyclic $C_n$). Explicit examples for composite $n$ (e.g., $n=6,8,9,10$) are valuable for testing and intuition. Connects to inverse Galois theory and explicit class field theory. A special case study for $n=6$ is proposed using $f(x)=x^6+x^3+1$ (cyclotomic polynomial $\Phi_9$).

directions.description: Study the statistical variance of the counting function $\pi_f(N) = |\{p \le N : p \in S_f\}|$ across random polynomials $f \in \mathcal{P}_n(H)$ (coefficients bounded by $H$). For fixed $N$ and large $H$, analyze the distribution of $X_{N,H}(f) = \pi_f(N) - \rho(S_n) \cdot \pi(N)$.
directions.comment: This direction is now enriched with a detailed motivation and potential proof methods from the new text. A special case study for $n=3$, $H=10$, $N=1000$ is suggested to estimate the variance of prime counts across random polynomials.

directions.description: Given a density value $r \in D_n$, characterize the fiber $\Phi_n^{-1}(r) = \{ G \in \mathcal{G}_n^{\text{real}} : \rho(G) = r \}$ of realizable transitive permutation groups of degree $n$ with fixed-point proportion $r$. Investigate group-theoretic properties shared by groups in the same fiber and whether $\Phi_n$ is injective for certain $n$.
directions.comment: Refines the density-equivalence concept (con_022). A special case study for $n=5$ is proposed to enumerate transitive groups ($C_5, D_5, F_{20}, A_5, S_5$), compute $\rho(G)$, and identify collisions (distinct groups with same $\rho$).

directions.description: Investigate the existence of a constant $c < 1$ such that no irreducible polynomial of any degree has density $d(f) \in (c, 1)$ (the gap conjecture). Study sequences of transitive permutation groups $G_n$ with $\rho(G_n) \to 1$ and determine the asymptotic behavior of $\rho_{\max}(n) = \max\{\rho(G) : G \text{ transitive of degree } n\}$.
directions.comment: Strengthens dir_015 and addresses conj_013. Known sequences ($S_n$, $A_n$) give $\rho \to 1-1/e \approx 0.632$. A special case study is proposed: compute $\rho(G)$ for primitive groups of small degree (≤30) to identify groups with $\rho(G) > 0.9$ and check realizability over $\mathbb{Q}$.

directions.description: Explore the relationship between the fixed-point graph $\Gamma_G$ (obj_014) and the density $\rho(G)$. Investigate whether connectivity or other graph properties correlate with $\rho(G)$. Characterize groups for which $\Gamma_G$ is complete (conj_007 suggests only trivial groups). Use the fixed-point lattice $L(G)$ (con_023) to bound $\rho(G)$.
directions.comment: A novel combinatorial approach to understanding Galois group structure. A special case study for degree 4 groups ($C_4, V_4, D_4, A_4, S_4$) is proposed: construct $\Gamma_G$, compute graph properties, and compare with $\rho(G)$.

directions.description: Extend the systematic enumeration to higher degrees $n = 5, 6$ with small coefficients. For each degree, enumerate all monic irreducible polynomials with coefficients in $[-H, H]$ for small $H$, compute their Galois groups, determine theoretical densities $\rho(G)$, and empirically verify by prime counting. Compare observed frequency of Galois groups with theoretical predictions from probabilistic Galois theory.
directions.comment: Natural extension of dir_012 to higher degrees. Would test whether the density spectrum $D_n$ matches theoretical predictions and provide empirical data on Galois group distributions for small-height polynomials.

directions.description: Investigate the relationship between the size of the discriminant $|\Delta(f)|$ and the empirical error $\text{Err}_f(N)$ in density verification. Hypothesis: Polynomials with larger discriminant require larger $N$ to achieve the same error bound due to slower convergence in Chebotarev.
directions.comment: Connects analytic number theory (error terms in Chebotarev) with computational verification. Could lead to guidelines for choosing $N$ based on discriminant when empirically testing densities.

directions.description: Study "exceptional" quartics with Galois group $A_4$ (density 3/4). Characterize the coefficient patterns that produce $A_4$ Galois groups. Find minimal-height examples and investigate whether there are infinite families of $A_4$ quartics with small coefficients.
directions.comment: $A_4$ quartics are rare but interesting due to their high density (3/4). Understanding their construction could illuminate inverse Galois theory for alternating groups.

directions.description: For a monic irreducible polynomial $f$ with non-abelian Galois group $G$, quantify the failure of the exceptional set $E_f$ to be described by congruence conditions. Investigate: 1) The minimal modulus $N$ for which a positive proportion of primes in $E_f$ obey a congruence condition. 2) The Fourier coefficients of the indicator function of $E_f$ and their decay. 3) The minimal possible density of $E_f$ that can be captured by a finite union of arithmetic progressions.
directions.comment: Inspired by the proof attempts for conj_009. Moves beyond the binary classification (congruential vs. not) to quantitative measures of non-congruentiality. Connects to analytic number theory (Dirichlet's theorem for non-abelian extensions) and the theory of Artin L-functions.

directions.description: For a monic irreducible polynomial $f$ with non-abelian Galois group $G$, investigate whether the exceptional set $E_f$ can be approximated in density by a finite union of arithmetic progressions. Determine the minimal possible error $\epsilon$ such that there exists a union of progressions $A$ with $d(E_f \triangle A) < \epsilon$, and how $\epsilon$ relates to the group structure of $G$.
directions.comment: A natural refinement of the qualitative result (lem_030). Asks how 'close' a non-congruential set can be to a congruential one. This is an approximation problem in prime number theory, linking to equidistribution and Chebotarev-constrained equidistribution (con_032).

directions.description: Given a monic irreducible polynomial $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ (e.g., by its coefficients), design an algorithm to decide whether its exceptional set $E_f$ is describable by congruence conditions, without fully computing the Galois group. Explore necessary and sufficient conditions based on polynomial invariants (discriminant, resolvent, etc.) and efficient heuristics.
directions.comment: An algorithmic challenge inspired by the proof of conj_009. The decision problem reduces to checking if the Galois group is abelian, but full Galois group computation is expensive. Seeks practical criteria or heuristics that can answer the congruentiality question more directly, possibly using local data or density estimates.

directions.description: Study the density equivalence classes $\mathcal{E}(G)$ and $\mathcal{E}_{\mathbb{Q}}(G)$. Investigate: 1) Finiteness: For a given rational $r$, is $\mathcal{E}^{-1}(r)$ finite? 2) Structural invariants: What group-theoretic properties (e.g., number of derangement conjugacy classes, size of largest derangement class) are invariant within a density class? 3) Realizability gaps: Are there rationals $r = \rho(G)$ for which $\mathcal{E}_{\mathbb{Q}}^{-1}(r)$ is empty (i.e., no group in the class is realizable over $\mathbb{Q}$)? 4) Relationship to the fibers $\Phi_n^{-1}(r)$ (obj_029).
directions.comment: Deepens the understanding of density-equivalence (con_033) beyond pairwise comparison. Aims to characterize which group structures yield the same arithmetic density, crucial for the inverse problem. Connects group theory to arithmetic statistics in a novel way.

directions.description: Investigate the minimal discriminant function $\Delta_{\min}(G; H)$ and its asymptotic behavior $\Delta_{\min}(G) = \liminf_{H \to \infty} \Delta_{\min}(G; H)$. Study: 1) Monotonicity: For realizable groups $G_1, G_2$ of same degree $n$, does $|G_1| < |G_2|$ imply $\Delta_{\min}(G_1) \leq \Delta_{\min}(G_2)$? 2) Correlation with density: For fixed $n$, is there a relationship between $\rho(G)$ and $\Delta_{\min}(G)$? 3) Growth rate: Determine the scaling of $\log \Delta_{\min}(G; H)$ with $H$; conjecture $\log \Delta_{\min}(G; H) \sim c_G \cdot n \log H$. 4) Explicit computation for small groups and degrees.
directions.comment: Refines dir_025 by focusing on Galois group rather than density. Seeks to connect algebraic complexity (discriminant) directly to Galois structure. Provides concrete targets for explicit construction (dir_016) and insights into the complexity of realizing specific Galois groups.

directions.description: Explore the prime splitting poset $P_G$ (or $P_f$). Investigate: 1) Invariance: Prove that $P_f$ depends only on the Galois group $G$ and its permutation representation. 2) Density formulas: Develop systematic methods to compute densities of primes lying in upward-closed subsets of $P_G$ (e.g., 'primes where $f$ has at least two roots'). 3) Connection to $L(G)$: Relate $P_G$ to the fixed-point lattice $L(G)$ (con_023); are they dual structures? 4) Compute $P_G$ for small groups (e.g., degree 4 groups) and identify universal features.
directions.comment: Synthesizes local splitting data into a global relational structure. Provides a framework for understanding dependencies between different Frobenius conditions, beyond just root existence. Could systematize density computations for complex splitting patterns and deepen the combinatorial understanding of Galois actions.

directions.description: Study the abelian congruence modulus $N_f^{\text{ab}}$. Investigate: 1) Divisibility: Does $N_f^{\text{ab}}$ divide the discriminant $\Delta_f$? Does it equal the conductor of the associated cyclotomic subfield? 2) Degree bound: For abelian polynomials of fixed degree $n$, can $N_f^{\text{ab}}$ be arbitrarily large? 3) Construction: Given an abelian group $G$ and a target modulus $N$, can one construct a polynomial $f$ with Galois group $G$ and $N_f^{\text{ab}} = N$? 4) Algorithmic computation: Develop methods to compute $N_f^{\text{ab}}$ from the coefficients of $f$.
directions.comment: Quantitative refinement of dir_028. Turns the qualitative description of abelian exceptional sets (lem_014) into a study of a canonical invariant. Aids in finding 'nice' explicit examples for abelian densities and understanding the complexity of abelian extensions.

directions.description: Analyze the density attainment function $A(r)$. Investigate: 1) Finiteness: Is $A(r) < \infty$ for all $r$ in the density spectrum $D$? 2) Growth: As $r$ approaches the conjectured upper bound $c$ (from conj_013) or the generic limit $1-1/e$, does $A(r) \to \infty$? 3) Monotonicity: Are there partial monotonicity properties? 4) Computation: Compute $A(r)$ for rationals with small denominator; determine $A(3/5)$, $A(5/8)$, etc. 5) Relationship to $\gamma(\epsilon)$: How does $A(r)$ relate to the gap function $\gamma(\epsilon)$ (obj_035)?
directions.comment: Functional formulation of the inverse problem. Mapping $A(r)$ reveals the landscape of realizable densities and the complexity (in terms of degree) required to achieve them. Strongly connected to the gap conjecture (conj_013) and the structure of $D_n$.

directions.description: Investigate the distribution of the logarithmic discriminant $\Lambda(f) = \log |\Delta_L|$ for random polynomials $f \in \mathcal{P}_n(H)$. Determine its mean, variance, and limiting distribution as $H \to \infty$. Relate this distribution to the error term $E_f(N)$ under GRH and to the variance of $\pi_f(N)$ across polynomials.
directions.comment: Links analytic number theory (error terms in Chebotarev) to arithmetic statistics (distribution of discriminants). A prerequisite for understanding the variance of $\pi_f(N)$ and testing conj_025. Connects to existing objects $\mathcal{P}_n(H)$ (obj_025) and $\Delta_{\min}(n, r)$ (obj_031).

directions.description: For a fixed Galois group $G$ (realizable over $\mathbb{Q}$), study the minimal possible splitting field discriminant $\Delta_L$ among polynomials $f$ with that Galois group. How does this minimal discriminant grow with $|G|$? Relate this minimal discriminant to the minimal error term in the Chebotarev density theorem for that group, and explore the discriminant–density trade-off.
directions.comment: Connects to the inverse problem (dir_016) and the discriminant–density trade-off concept. Could lead to explicit bounds for error terms tailored to specific Galois groups, refining conj_024. Relates to existing objects $\Delta_{\min}(G; H)$ (obj_042) and $\Delta_{\min}(n, r)$ (obj_031).

directions.description: For each rational $r = a/b$ in lowest terms with denominator $b \le B$ (e.g., $B=20$), compute $\nu(r)$ (or $A(r)$) by: 1) Enumerating transitive permutation groups of increasing degree $n$ (using GAP). 2) For each group $G$, computing $\rho(G)$. 3) Checking realizability of $G$ over $\mathbb{Q}$ (using known databases or theorems). 4) Recording the smallest $n$ where $\rho(G) = r$.
directions.comment: This would produce a table of minimal degrees for common fractions, answering concrete instances of dir_014. It bridges group theory, number theory, and computation. The results could reveal patterns, e.g., whether $\nu(r)$ is typically close to $\lceil 1/r \rceil$ or much larger. A natural extension of the systematic enumeration done for quartics (dir_012).

directions.description: For a given transitive permutation group $G$ of degree $n$ realizable over $\mathbb{Q}$, study its density-realization spectrum $\Psi_n^{\text{ref}}(G)$ (con_034). This is the set of all densities $\rho_U(G) = |U|/|G|$ where $U$ is a union of conjugacy classes of $G$. Investigate: 1) Determine $\Psi_n^{\text{ref}}(G)$ explicitly. 2) Characterize which unions $U$ correspond to natural Frobenius conditions (e.g., '$f$ splits completely modulo $p$', '$f$ has exactly $k$ roots modulo $p$'). 3) Determine whether $\Psi_n^{\text{ref}}(G)$ is always an interval of rational numbers with denominator $|G|$, or if it can have gaps. 4) Explore the relationship between $\Psi_n^{\text{ref}}(G)$ and the lattice of subgroups of $G$ (via Galois correspondence).
directions.comment: Generalizes the classification of densities from root existence to arbitrary splitting patterns. Connects to the inverse problem (dir_014, dir_016) and refines the map $\Psi_n$ (obj_030). Understanding these spectra could reveal new constraints on Galois groups and their realizability. A special case study for $G = S_4$ is suggested.

directions.description: For fixed degree $n$ and density $r \in D_n$, investigate the minimal discriminant $\Delta_{\min}(n, r)$ (obj_031, con_035). 1) For small $n$ (e.g., $n=3,4$), compute $\Delta_{\min}(n, r)$ exactly by searching among polynomials with small coefficients and known Galois groups. 2) Establish general lower bounds for $\Delta_{\min}(n, r)$ in terms of $n$ and $r$, possibly using analytic tools. 3) Explore the relationship: does $\Delta_{\min}(n, r)$ increase with $r$? Is it minimized at the minimal density $r = 1/n$? 4) For $r = 1/n$, conjecture that the minimizer is a cyclotomic polynomial (or a subfield polynomial) with minimal conductor.
directions.comment: Links the arithmetic statistic (density) to algebraic complexity (discriminant). Refines the explicit construction problem (dir_016) by asking for the 'simplest' polynomial with a given density. Results could inform computational searches and provide insights into the distribution of discriminants across density fibers. A special case study for $n=4$, $r=3/4$ (density achieved by $A_4$ quartics) is suggested.

directions.description: Study the statistical distribution of the counting function $\pi_f(N) = |\{p \le N : p \in S_f\}|$ as $f$ varies over $\mathcal{P}_n(H)$ (polynomials of degree $n$ with coefficients bounded by $H$). Define the random variable $X_{N,H}(f) = \pi_f(N) - \rho(S_n) \cdot \pi(N)$. Investigate: 1) As $H \to \infty$, what is the limiting distribution of $X_{N,H}(f)$ (suitably normalized)? Is it Gaussian? 2) How does the variance $\text{Var}_{f \in \mathcal{P}_n(H)}[\pi_f(N)]$ depend on $N$ and $H$? 3) Compare the variance for polynomials with different Galois groups (e.g., $S_n$ vs. $C_n$).
directions.comment: Merges analytic number theory (error terms in Chebotarev) with statistics. Explores fluctuations around the generic behavior predicted by probabilistic Galois theory. Could reveal how 'typical' the generic behavior is and how quickly convergence occurs. A special case study for $n=3$, $H=10$, $N=1000$ is suggested.

directions.description: Investigate the density gap function $\gamma(\epsilon)$ (obj_035), which measures the largest degree $n$ for which there exists a polynomial with density $> 1-\epsilon$. Formally, $\gamma(\epsilon) = \sup \{ n : D_n \cap (1-\epsilon, 1) \neq \emptyset \}$. 1) Compute $\gamma(\epsilon)$ for small $\epsilon$ using known classifications of transitive groups (up to some degree, say $n \le 30$). 2) Establish upper bounds on $\gamma(\epsilon)$ in terms of $\epsilon$, possibly using permutation group theory (bounds on derangement proportions). 3) Conjecture whether $\gamma(\epsilon)$ is finite for all $\epsilon > 0$ (the Gap Conjecture, conj_013). If finite, determine its growth rate (e.g., polynomial, exponential in $1/\epsilon$).
directions.comment: Quantifies how close densities can get to 1 as a function of degree. A finite $\gamma(\epsilon)$ for all $\epsilon$ would imply a uniform upper bound $c < 1$ on $d(f)$ for all nonlinear $f$, resolving conj_013 positively. A special case study to compute $\gamma(0.1)$, $\gamma(0.05)$, $\gamma(0.01)$ for $n \le 30$ is suggested.

directions.description: Explore the relationship between the fixed-point graph $\Gamma_G$ (obj_014) and the density $\rho(G)$. 1) For transitive groups $G$ of small degree, construct $\Gamma_G$ explicitly and compute graph invariants: connectivity, diameter, clustering coefficient, etc. 2) Test whether $\rho(G)$ correlates with these invariants. For example, does higher connectivity correspond to higher density? 3) Characterize groups for which $\Gamma_G$ is connected. Is connectivity equivalent to some group-theoretic property (e.g., $G$ generated by elements with fixed points)? 4) Study the fixed-point lattice $L(G)$ (con_023) and its automorphism group $\operatorname{Aut}(L(G))$ (obj_033). Does the lattice isomorphism type determine $\rho(G)$?
directions.comment: Bridges group theory, graph theory, and number theory. The fixed-point graph is a novel combinatorial object encoding how fixed-point sets intersect. May provide a structural way to understand density $\rho(G)$ and lead to new bounds. A special case study for all transitive groups of degree 4 ($C_4, V_4, D_4, A_4, S_4$) is suggested.

directions.description: Study the asymptotic behavior of the counting function $N_n(r; H)$ (obj_032), which counts polynomials of degree $n$ with coefficients bounded by $H$ having density $r$. 1) For $r \neq \rho(S_n)$, conjecture a power-law growth: $N_n(r; H) \sim c_{n,r} H^{n - \alpha_{n,r}}$ as $H \to \infty$. Determine the exponent $\alpha_{n,r}$ and relate it to the dimension of the moduli space of polynomials with Galois group $G$ (where $\rho(G)=r$). 2) Investigate whether $\alpha_{n,r}$ decreases as $r$ approaches $\rho(S_n)$ from below, reflecting that polynomials with densities near the generic value are 'less rare'. 3) For $r = \rho(S_n)$, the generic case, study the secondary term: $|\mathcal{P}_n(H)| - N_n(\rho(S_n); H) \sim ?$
directions.comment: Quantifies probabilistic Galois theory results, moving beyond qualitative 'density 0 vs. 1' to measure how quickly non-generic densities become rare. The exponents $\alpha_{n,r}$ are geometric invariants that could classify density fibers by their 'size' in the parameter space. A special case study for $n=4$, $r=1/4$ is suggested.

directions.description: For each $n = 2$ to $10$, enumerate all transitive permutation groups of degree $n$, compute $\rho(G)$, determine which are realizable over $\mathbb{Q}$, and compile a complete table $T_n$. Use this to answer dir_016 for any rational $r$ with small denominator.
directions.comment: A computational project that would provide a definitive reference for small-degree density realization. Builds on the systematic enumeration done for quartics (dir_012) and extends it to higher degrees. Essential for solving the inverse problem concretely.

directions.description: Given $r = a/b$ with $b$ such that the cyclic group $C_b$ is realizable over $\mathbb{Q}$ (i.e., $b$ is any positive integer), construct an explicit polynomial $f$ with $d(f) = 1/b$ (minimal density). More generally, for abelian groups $G$, provide an algorithm to produce $f$ with $d(f) = \rho(G)$ using cyclotomic fields.
directions.comment: Solves a large subclass of dir_016 explicitly. Abelian groups are fully realizable via Kronecker-Weber, so the challenge is to produce explicit polynomials with given Galois group and density. Connects to explicit class field theory and cyclotomic polynomials.

directions.description: Study the set $D \cap (c,1)$ for $c$ close to 1. Determine whether there is a gap, i.e., does there exist $c < 1$ such that no density lies in $(c,1)$? This is related to conj_013 and dir_015.
directions.comment: A deep open problem that affects the existence of polynomials with density arbitrarily close to 1. The new text reframes this as studying the asymptotics of the density spectrum. Connects to permutation group theory (maximal fixed-point proportions) and inverse Galois realizability.

conjectures.statement: If $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ is a monic irreducible polynomial, and there exist infinitely many primes $p$ such that $f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod p$ has a solution in $\mathbb{F}_p$, then $f(x)$ must have a linear factor over $\mathbb{Z}$ (i.e., $\deg(f) = 1$).
conjectures.comment: Conjecture has been disproven via two counterexamples: $f(x) = x^2 + 1$ and $f(x) = x^3 - 2$. Both are monic, irreducible over $\mathbb{Z}$, and have infinitely many primes $p$ with a root modulo $p$, but have degrees 2 and 3 respectively. The special case study of quadratic polynomials shows that ANY monic irreducible quadratic automatically satisfies the condition (density 1/2), providing an infinite family of counterexamples. The correct threshold is 'almost all primes' (density 1): if $f(x)$ has a root modulo $p$ for all but finitely many primes, then $\deg(f)=1$ (this is a known theorem).

conjectures.statement: If $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ is monic and irreducible, and the density $d(f)$ of primes $p$ for which $f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod p$ has a solution equals 1, then $\deg(f) = 1$.
conjectures.comment: Confirmed as a theorem. The group-theoretic lemma (Jordan's theorem) proves that if every element of a transitive permutation group has a fixed point, then the group is trivial. Combined with Chebotarev density theorem (d(f)=1 implies every Frobenius element fixes a root, hence every group element fixes a root), this forces deg(f)=1. This resolves dir_003 and dir_005. **Proof details:** The set H = {g ∈ G : g fixes at least one root} is a union of conjugacy classes. For unramified primes p, p ∈ S_f iff the Frobenius conjugacy class C_p ⊆ H. By Chebotarev, d(f)=|H|/|G|. Given d(f)=1, H=G. Since G acts transitively on the roots and every element has a fixed point, Jordan's theorem forces the number of roots to be 1, i.e., deg(f)=1. Ramified primes are finite and do not affect density.

conjectures.statement: For a monic irreducible polynomial $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ of degree $n \geq 2$, the density $d(f)$ of primes with a root modulo $p$ satisfies $d(f) \leq 1 - \frac{1}{|G|}$, where $G$ is the Galois group of $f$ over $\mathbb{Q}$.
conjectures.comment: The bound d(f) ≤ 1 - 1/|G| is universal but not always tight. For n=2, equality holds (irreducible quadratics). For n ≥ 3, the bound is strict; the true maximum density d_max(n) is strictly less than 1 - 1/|G|. A refined conjecture (conj_012) proposes a tighter bound involving the minimal number of derangements δ(G). Equality occurs only when the set of derangements is a single conjugacy class (e.g., in S_n, derangements form a single conjugacy class only for n=2,3).

conjectures.statement: For a monic irreducible polynomial $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ with abelian Galois group, the exceptional set $E_f$ is described by congruence conditions modulo an integer $N_f$ (related to the discriminant).
conjectures.comment: Proven. For a monic irreducible polynomial f(x) with abelian Galois group, the exceptional set E_f is described, up to finitely many primes, by congruence conditions modulo the conductor m of the abelian extension. Specifically, E_f = { p prime (unramified) : p mod m ∉ H } ∪ {finite set}, where H is the subgroup of (ℤ/mℤ)^× corresponding to the splitting field. This provides a concrete characterization of primes where f has no root. The new text provides a detailed proof via Kronecker-Weber.

conjectures.statement: For each $n \ge 2$, the density spectrum $D_n$ is a finite set of rational numbers.
conjectures.comment: Follows from Chebotarev: $d(f) = |H|/|G|$ where $G$ is a transitive permutation group of degree $n$ and $H = \{g \in G : g \text{ fixes at least one root}\}$. Since there are finitely many such groups $G$ (up to isomorphism) and each yields finitely many possible $|H|/|G|$ values (depending on which conjugacy classes are included in $H$), $D_n$ should be finite. The challenge is determining which groups are realizable as Galois groups over $\mathbb{Q}$.

conjectures.statement: For $n \ge 2$, the minimal positive density in $D_n$ is $1/n$.
conjectures.comment: Now proven (lem_019). The minimal density d_min(n)=1/n is attained by polynomials with regular Galois action (e.g., cyclic C_n). The proof uses fixed-point counting (Burnside's lemma) and realizability of cyclic groups over ℚ (Kronecker-Weber). For small n, this can be verified against classifications of transitive groups.

conjectures.statement: For a transitive permutation group $G$ of degree $n \ge 2$, if the fixed-point graph $\Gamma_G$ (undirected version) is complete, then every element of $G$ shares a common fixed point, forcing $n=1$ (contradiction) unless $G$ is trivial.
conjectures.comment: The conjecture has been proven true, but its hypothesis is impossible for $n \ge 2$. The proof shows that any transitive permutation group $G$ with $n \ge 2$ contains a derangement (by Jordan's theorem), which becomes an isolated vertex in $\Gamma_G$, making completeness impossible. Therefore, the implication is vacuously true. This resolves the exploration of the fixed-point graph's completeness property.

conjectures.statement: For every $n \geq 2$, there exists a monic irreducible polynomial $f$ of degree $n$ such that $d(E_f) = 1 - 1/n$. Equivalently, $d_{\min}(n) = 1/n$.
conjectures.comment:
**Original Motivation:** The cyclic group $C_n$ has $\rho(C_n)=1/n$. By inverse Galois theory for abelian groups, $C_n$ is realizable as a Galois group over $\mathbb{Q}$. Construct $f$ with Galois group $C_n$ (e.g., using subfields of cyclotomic fields). Then $d(f)=1/n$, so $d(E_f)=1-1/n$. The conjecture that this is maximal follows from the belief that no transitive group of degree $n$ has $\rho(G) < 1/n$.

**Proof History & Accumulated Experience:**
Multiple proof attempts were made, all following the same core strategy: (1) Relate $d(E_f)$ to $d(f)$ via complementarity, (2) Prove the universal lower bound $d(f) \ge 1/n$ using Burnside's lemma and Chebotarev, (3) Construct an explicit polynomial with Galois group $C_n$ to show attainability.

**Key Obstacles & Insights from Failures:**
1.  **Precise Density Relationship:** The equality $d(E_f) = 1 - d(f)$ requires careful handling of ramified primes. The correct justification is that $S_f$ and $E_f$ partition the unramified primes (a set of density 1), so the densities are complementary (lem_017). This must be stated clearly to avoid logical gaps.
2.  **Deriving the Lower Bound:** The most common error was a flawed application of Burnside's lemma to derive $d(f) \ge 1/n$. The correct argument uses the upper bound $|\operatorname{Fix}(g)| \le n$ for $g \in H$ (elements with fixed points). From Burnside: $|G| = \sum_{g\in H} |\operatorname{Fix}(g)| \le n\cdot|H|$, hence $|H| \ge |G|/n$ and $\rho(G) \ge 1/n$. Several attempts incorrectly used lower bounds on $|\operatorname{Fix}(g)|$ or manipulated inequalities in the wrong direction, leading to invalid conclusions.
3.  **Constructive Existence:** Proving attainability requires: (a) Realizability of $C_n$ over $\mathbb{Q}$ (via Kronecker-Weber: for any $n$, choose prime $m \equiv 1 \pmod n$; the unique subfield of $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_m)$ of degree $n$ is cyclic). (b) Ensuring the constructed polynomial's Galois group acts *regularly* on its roots. This follows because in a Galois extension of degree $n$ with cyclic group, the action on the roots of a primitive element's minimal polynomial is simply transitive (stabilizers are trivial). This point was often assumed without explicit justification.
4.  **Quantifier Precision:** Statements like "any polynomial with regular Galois action achieves $d(f)=1/n$" are true, but the converse (only such polynomials achieve it) is not necessarily true. The existence proof only requires one example, not a classification.

**Suggested New Exploration Directions (Inspired by Attempts):**
While the conjecture is now proven (see lem_019 and lem_031), the attempts highlight related open problems and refinements:
1.  **Characterization of Minimizers:** Which polynomials (beyond those with regular Galois action) achieve $d(f)=1/n$? Study the fiber $\Phi_n^{-1}(1/n)$ of Galois groups with $\rho(G)=1/n$. Are there non-regular groups with this property? This refines the inverse problem for minimal density.
2.  **Explicit Minimal Discriminant:** Among polynomials of degree $n$ with $d(f)=1/n$, what is the minimal possible discriminant? For $n=6$, the cyclotomic polynomial $\Phi_9(x)=x^6+x^3+1$ gives $d(f)=1/6$. Is its discriminant minimal? This connects to the object $\Delta_{\min}(n, r)$ (obj_031).
3.  **Statistical Rarity:** How rare are polynomials with $d(f)=1/n$ among those with bounded coefficients? Study the asymptotic growth of $N_n(1/n; H)$ (obj_032) as $H \to \infty$. This quantifies the "size" of the minimal density fiber in parameter space.
4.  **Abelian Exceptional Set Structure:** For a polynomial $f$ with $d(f)=1/n$ (cyclic Galois group), the exceptional set $E_f$ has density $1-1/n$ and is described by congruence conditions (lem_014). Investigate the minimal modulus $N_f^{\text{ab}}$ (obj_044) for such polynomials. How does it relate to the conductor and discriminant?

**Conclusion for Subsequent Workers:**
Conjecture conj_008 is settled. The proof is a straightforward application of Burnside's lemma (for the lower bound) and classical inverse Galois theory for cyclic groups (for attainability). Future work should not attempt to reprove this result but can build upon it, exploring the characterization, explicitness, and statistics of minimal-density polynomials as outlined above. The failed attempts serve as a reminder to handle Burnside's lemma inequalities with care and to fully justify the regularity of the Galois action in constructive proofs.

conjectures.statement: If $f$ has non-abelian Galois group $G$, then $E_f$ cannot be expressed as a finite union of arithmetic progressions (except in degenerate cases where $G$ is actually abelian).
conjectures.comment:
**Original Motivation & Status:** This conjecture, now a proven theorem (lem_030), states that the exceptional set \(E_f\) (primes where \(f\) has no root modulo \(p\)) is describable by congruence conditions (a finite union of arithmetic progressions) if and only if the Galois group \(G\) of \(f\) is abelian. The 'if' direction follows from class field theory (Kronecker-Weber). The 'only if' direction, that non-abelian \(G\) forces \(E_f\) to be non-congruential, is the core claim.

**Proof Attempt History & Accumulated Experience:**
Multiple proof attempts were made, all based on the same core strategy: assume \(E_f\) is a union of arithmetic progressions modulo \(N\), use Chebotarev to link this to the Frobenius condition \(\operatorname{Frob}_p \subseteq C_{\text{der}}\) (derangements), and then deduce that the set of derangements \(C_{\text{der}}\) must be a union of cosets of the commutator subgroup \([G,G]\). The goal was to derive a contradiction with the non-abelian hypothesis.

**Key Obstacles & Insights from Failures:**
1.  **Structural Control of \(C_{\text{der}}\):** The main difficulty was correctly and rigorously deducing the structure of \(C_{\text{der}}\) from the congruence assumption. The successful argument (lem_030) shows that congruence description forces the characteristic function of \(E_f\) to factor through the abelianization of \(G\), implying \(C_{\text{der}}\) is a union of fibers of the map to \(G^{\text{ab}}\). This is a cleaner, more direct approach than the attempts, which often got entangled in flawed arguments about the action of \([G,G]\) on the roots.
2.  **Pitfall: Action of the Commutator Subgroup:** Several attempts incorrectly tried to use the condition "every element of \([G,G]\) fixes a root" to force \([G,G]\) to act trivially, via flawed invariance or orbit arguments. The lesson is that this condition alone is insufficient; one must use the stronger structural fact that \(C_{\text{der}}\) is a union of cosets of \([G,G]\), which isolates \([G,G]\) from \(C_{\text{der}}\) entirely.
3.  **Technical Precision:** Common errors included imprecise handling of ramified primes, misstatements about the surjectivity of restriction maps, and incorrect applications of Chebotarev (e.g., confusing elements with conjugacy classes). The final proof requires careful attention to these technicalities.
4.  **Simpler Path:** The attempts revealed that a successful proof avoids intricate analysis of the permutation action of \([G,G]\). Instead, it leverages the functoriality of the Artin map and the fact that periodicity modulo \(N\) corresponds to factoring through the cyclotomic field \(\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_N)\), which is abelian.

**Suggested New Exploration Directions (Inspired by Attempts):**
While the conjecture is proven, the attempts highlight related open problems:
1.  **Quantitative Non-Congruence:** For a non-abelian \(G\), how can one quantify the failure of \(E_f\) to be congruential? For example, study the minimal modulus \(N\) for which a positive proportion of primes in \(E_f\) obey a congruence condition, or analyze the Fourier coefficients of the indicator function of \(E_f\).
2.  **Approximate Congruences:** Could \(E_f\) be approximated (in density) by a finite union of arithmetic progressions? What is the minimal error possible? This connects to Dirichlet's theorem for non-abelian extensions and the theory of Artin L-functions.
3.  **Algorithmic Recognition:** Given a polynomial \(f\) (e.g., by its coefficients), can one algorithmically decide if \(E_f\) is congruential without fully computing the Galois group? This is a refinement of the inverse Galois problem.

**Conclusion for Subsequent Workers:**
Conjecture conj_009 is settled. The proof is a model application of the Chebotarev density theorem combined with the Kronecker-Weber theorem. Future work should not attempt to reprove this result but can build upon it, exploring the quantitative and algorithmic questions outlined above. The failed attempts serve as a cautionary tale about the subtleties in moving from density statements to exact structural descriptions of prime sets.

conjectures.statement: For each $n \geq 2$, among all transitive permutation groups $G$ of degree $n$ realizable over $\mathbb{Q}$, the symmetric group $S_n$ maximizes the fixed-point proportion $\rho(G)$. That is, $\rho(S_n) = \max_{G \in \mathcal{G}_n^{\mathbb{Q}}} \rho(G)$, where $\mathcal{G}_n^{\mathbb{Q}}$ is the set of realizable groups.
conjectures.comment: Supported by known values for $n \leq 4$: $\rho(S_2)=1/2$, $\rho(S_3)=2/3$, $\rho(S_4)=5/8$, all of which are maximal in their respective $D_n$. For $n=4$, note that $A_4$ gives $\rho=3/4 > 5/8$, but $A_4$ is not the full symmetric group. This suggests the maximum might sometimes be achieved by $A_n$ rather than $S_n$. Needs verification for larger $n$.

conjectures.statement: For each $n \geq 5$, the proportion of degree-$n$ monic irreducible polynomials with Galois group $S_n$ approaches 1 at rate $O(1/H^c)$ for some $c > 0$ as $H \to \infty$. More precisely, there exists $c_n > 0$ such that: $\frac{|\{f \in \mathcal{P}_n(H) : \text{Gal}(f) \not\cong S_n\}|}{|\mathcal{P}_n(H)|} = O\left(\frac{1}{H^{c_n}}\right)$.
conjectures.comment: Refines the generic behavior statement. The convergence rate is important for understanding how quickly the distribution concentrates around $\rho(S_n)$. Empirical evidence suggests $c_n$ decreases with $n$.

conjectures.statement: Let $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ be monic, irreducible of degree $n \geq 2$ with Galois group $G$. Then $d(f) \leq 1 - \frac{\delta(G)}{|G|}$, where $\delta(G)$ is the minimal number of derangements in any transitive permutation group of degree $n$ isomorphic to $G$. Moreover, for each $n$, the maximum possible density $d_{\max}(n)$ equals $1 - \frac{\delta_{\min}(n)}{|G_{\max}|}$, where $\delta_{\min}(n)$ is the minimum number of derangements among all transitive groups of degree $n$ realizable over $\mathbb{Q}$, and $G_{\max}$ is a group attaining that minimum.
conjectures.comment: Arises from the observation that the bound $1 - 1/|G|$ is not tight for $n \geq 3$. This conjecture refines the upper bound by incorporating the minimal number of derangements in the group. It connects the extremal density problem to the combinatorial structure of derangements in permutation groups.

conjectures.statement: There exists a constant c < 1 such that for all monic irreducible polynomials f(x) ∈ ℤ[x] of any degree n ≥ 2, the density d(f) ≤ c. Equivalently, the density spectrum D = ⋃_{n≥2} D_n is bounded away from 1.
conjectures.comment: Now formally connected to the Spectral Gap Constant $c^*$. The deep exploration suggests a refined conjecture (conj_024) that $c^* = 1 - \limsup \rho(A_n)$. The problem reduces to studying the asymptotic maximum fixed-point proportion among transitive permutation groups $\rho_{\max}^{\text{theor}}(n)$ and its realizability over $\mathbb{Q}$.

conjectures.statement: For each $n \ge 5$, among all transitive permutation groups $G$ of degree $n$ realizable over $\mathbb{Q}$, the symmetric group $S_n$ maximizes the fixed-point proportion $\rho(G)$, except possibly for finitely many small $n$ (like $n=4$).
conjectures.comment: Natural refinement after the $n=4$ counterexample. For $n=5$, $S_5$ has higher proportion than $A_5$. For larger $n$, $\rho(S_n) \to 1-1/e \approx 0.632$, while $\rho(A_n)$ needs computation. Requires investigation for $n=6,7,\ldots$.

conjectures.statement: For any realizable transitive permutation group $G$ of degree $n$, the density-realization spectrum $\Psi_n^{\text{ref}}(G)$ is finite and consists of rational numbers of the form $m/|G|$ with $1 \le m \le |G|$. The minimal element is $1/|G|$ (corresponding to $U = \{\text{identity}\}$) and the maximal element is $\rho(G)$ (corresponding to $U = H$, the set of elements with at least one fixed point).
conjectures.comment: Natural extension of the fact that densities are rational with denominator $|G|$. Follows from the definition of $\rho_U(G)$ and finiteness of conjugacy classes.

conjectures.statement: For each $n$ and $r \in D_n$, the minimal discriminant $\Delta_{\min}(n, r)$ is finite and attained by some polynomial $f \in \mathcal{P}_n$. Moreover, the minimizing polynomial has the smallest possible Galois group order among those realizing $r$.
conjectures.comment: Plausible by compactness arguments (height vs. discriminant). The second part suggests that minimal discriminant correlates with minimal group size, which is intuitive but needs verification.

conjectures.statement: For each $r \in D_n \setminus \{\rho(S_n)\}$, there exists a constant $\alpha_{n,r} > 0$ such that $N_n(r; H) \asymp H^{n - \alpha_{n,r}}$ as $H \to \infty$. The exponent $\alpha_{n,r}$ is related to the dimension of the moduli space of polynomials with Galois group $G$ (where $\rho(G)=r$).
conjectures.comment: Consistent with heuristic that polynomials with non-generic Galois groups lie on lower-dimensional families. The exponent should reflect the number of free parameters in such families.

conjectures.statement: If $\rho(G_1) = \rho(G_2)$ and $|G_1| = |G_2|$, then the fixed-point lattices $L(G_1)$ and $L(G_2)$ are isomorphic if and only if $G_1$ and $G_2$ are permutation isomorphic.
conjectures.comment: Suggests that the lattice captures the group structure beyond just the density. Could be false if non-isomorphic groups share the same lattice structure.

conjectures.statement: For abelian $f$ of degree $n$, the minimal modulus $N_f^{\min}$ divides the discriminant $\Delta_f$ and equals the conductor of the associated cyclotomic subfield.
conjectures.comment: Expected from class field theory: the conductor is the minimal modulus for the Artin map, and it divides the discriminant.

conjectures.statement: The density gap function $\gamma(\epsilon)$ is finite for every $\epsilon > 0$ (Gap Conjecture). That is, there exists a constant $c < 1$ such that $d(f) \le c$ for all monic irreducible $f$ with $\deg(f) \ge 2$.
conjectures.comment: Restatement of conj_013. Supported by known sequences (e.g., $S_n$, $A_n$) yielding densities bounded away from 1, but not proven.

conjectures.statement: For monic irreducible quartic polynomials $f(x) = x^4 + a x^3 + b x^2 + c x + d$ with integer coefficients bounded by $H$, the proportion of polynomials with Galois group $A_4$ is $\Theta(1/H)$ as $H \to \infty$. More precisely, there exist constants $c_1, c_2 > 0$ such that $c_1/H \leq F_4(H, A_4) \leq c_2/H$ for all sufficiently large $H$.
conjectures.comment: Based on enumeration where only 3 out of 186 polynomials (1.6%) had $A_4$ Galois group for $H=3$. The condition for $A_4$ imposes algebraic constraints that become rarer as coefficient size increases. Refines generic behavior statement.

conjectures.statement: For any monic irreducible quartic polynomial $f$ with Galois group $V_4$ or $C_4$ (density 1/4), the discriminant $\Delta(f)$ is always a perfect square. Conversely, if $\Delta(f)$ is a perfect square and the resolvent cubic splits completely over $\mathbb{Q}$, then the Galois group is $V_4$; if $\Delta(f)$ is a perfect square and the resolvent cubic is irreducible over $\mathbb{Q}$, then the Galois group is either $C_4$ or $A_4$.
conjectures.comment: Observed in all 17 polynomials with density 0.25 in the enumeration. Provides a clean discriminant test for low-density quartics.

conjectures.statement: For monic irreducible quartic polynomials with small integer coefficients ($|a|,|b|,|c|,|d| \leq H$), the empirical density error $\text{Err}_f(N)$ when counting primes up to $N = 10000$ satisfies: $\text{Err}_f(N) \leq 0.01$ for at least 95% of such polynomials, and $\max_f \text{Err}_f(N) \leq 0.02$.
conjectures.comment: Based on systematic verification of 186 polynomials. Quantifies practical accuracy of Chebotarev density theorem for finite $N$ with quartics.

conjectures.statement: Under GRH, for a monic irreducible polynomial $f$ of degree $n$ with splitting field $L$ (discriminant $\Delta_L$) and Galois group $G$, the error term satisfies $E_f(N) = \pi_f(N) - \frac{|H|}{|G|} \operatorname{Li}(N) = O\left( \sqrt{N} (\log |\Delta_L| + |G| \log N) \right)$, where $H = \{g \in G : g \text{ fixes at least one root}\}$, and the implied constant is absolute. Moreover, for 'generic' polynomials (with Galois group $S_n$), this bound is sharp up to constants.
conjectures.comment: Refines the effective Chebotarev bound (lem_026) by making the dependence on $|G|$ explicit. Provides a concrete link between Galois group structure and error term magnitude, essential for variance analysis in dir_017.

conjectures.statement: For random monic irreducible polynomials $f \in \mathcal{P}_n(H)$ (with $H \to \infty$), the normalized error $\mathcal{E}_f(N) = \frac{\pi_f(N) - d(f) \operatorname{Li}(N)}{\sqrt{N} \log N}$ converges in distribution to a normal distribution with mean $0$ and variance $\sigma_n^2(N)$, where $\sigma_n^2(N) \sim c_n (\log H)^2 N (\log N)^2$ for some constant $c_n > 0$.
conjectures.comment: Heuristic conjecture based on analogy with sums over primes and the distribution of $\Lambda(f)$. Suggests a central limit theorem for prime counting deviations across random polynomials, offering a statistical perspective on the error term variance.

conjectures.statement: The Spectral Gap Constant $c^*$ is positive. Specifically, $c^* = 1 - \limsup_{n\to\infty} \rho(A_n)$. Furthermore, $\limsup_{n\to\infty} d_{\max}(n) = \lim_{n\to\infty} \rho(A_n) < 1$.
conjectures.comment: Refines the Gap Conjecture (conj_013). Basis: 1) For $n=4$, $A_4$ is the maximizer. 2) For primitive permutation groups, results limit the proportion of derangements, suggesting groups with $\rho(G)$ very close to 1 must be 'close' to $A_n$ or $S_n$, whose densities are bounded away from 1. 3) No known family of realizable groups has densities tending to 1.

conjectures.statement: There exists an integer $N$ such that for all $n \ge N$, the symmetric group $S_n$ is an element of $\mathcal{G}_n^{\text{max-real}}$. Furthermore, for all sufficiently large $n$, $\mathcal{G}_n^{\text{max-real}} = \{ S_n \}$.
conjectures.comment: Refinement of conj_014. Basis: 1) Probabilistic Galois theory indicates $S_n$ is the 'generic' Galois group, and its density $\rho(S_n) \to 1-1/e$ is a natural attractor. 2) While some primitive groups can have higher proportions for small $n$, the proportion of derangements in $S_n$ is conjectured to be asymptotically minimal among all transitive groups of large degree. The conjecture asserts that the realizability constraint does not change the asymptotic winner.

conjectures.statement: Let $f$ be a monic irreducible polynomial of degree $n \ge 2$ with Galois group $G$. If $G$ is primitive (as a permutation group on the roots), then $d(f) \le 1 - c/n$ for some absolute constant $c > 0$. In particular, for primitive groups, $d(f)$ is bounded away from 1 as $n$ grows.
conjectures.comment: Inspired by known results in permutation group theory: a theorem of Cameron, Neumann, and Saxl implies that the proportion of derangements in a primitive permutation group of degree $n$ is at least $c/n$ for some $c>0$. This would directly imply $\rho(G) \le 1 - c/n$. Since most interesting Galois groups (like $S_n, A_n$, most simple groups) are primitive, this strongly supports the Gap Property.

conjectures.statement: For any rational $r \in (0,1)$, if $r \in D_n$ for some $n$, then for all $m \ge n$, $r \in D_m$ (i.e., once a density is realizable at degree $n$, it is realizable at all higher degrees).
conjectures.comment: Heuristic: If we have a polynomial $f$ of degree $n$ with density $r$, we might construct a polynomial of degree $m > n$ with the same density by field compositum or other Galois-theoretic constructions. However, this is not straightforward (products of polynomials may not be irreducible). If true, it simplifies the search for minimal degree. Needs further investigation.

conjectures.statement: Let $r = a/b \in D$ in lowest terms. Then $b$ divides the order of some transitive permutation group of degree $\operatorname{mindeg}(r)$. Moreover, $b$ divides $n!$ where $n = \operatorname{mindeg}(r)$.
conjectures.comment: Since $\rho(G) = |H|/|G|$, the denominator divides $|G|$, which divides $n!$. The first part is trivial from the definition. The conjecture formalizes a basic necessary condition on the denominator of a realizable density.

conjectures.statement: For each integer $b \ge 2$, the set $\{ a/b \in D : \gcd(a,b)=1 \}$ is finite. That is, only finitely many densities with denominator $b$ are achievable across all degrees.
conjectures.comment: Motivation: There are finitely many transitive groups of any given order (up to isomorphism), each yields finitely many densities. Since denominator divides group order, for fixed $b$, only finitely many group orders can produce denominator $b$. However, as degree grows, new denominators appear; the conjecture claims this set is finite overall. Needs verification via enumeration.

lemmas.statement: $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ is monic and irreducible.
lemmas.proof: Conditional assumption

lemmas.statement: There exist infinitely many primes $p$ such that the congruence $f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod p$ has a solution in $\mathbb{F}_p$.
lemmas.proof: Conditional assumption

lemmas.statement: The conjecture 'If $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ is a monic irreducible polynomial, and there exist infinitely many primes $p$ such that $f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod p$ has a solution in $\mathbb{F}_p$, then $f(x)$ must have a linear factor over $\mathbb{Z}$ (i.e., $\deg(f) = 1$)' is false.
lemmas.proof: Counterexample: $f(x) = x^2 + 1$. Verification: 1) $f(x)$ is monic. 2) $f(x)$ is irreducible over $\mathbb{Z}$: if it factored as $(x+a)(x+b)$ with integers $a,b$, then $a+b=0$ and $ab=1$, implying $a^2 = -1$, impossible for integer $a$. 3) There exist infinitely many primes $p$ such that $f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod p$ has a solution: this is equivalent to $-1$ being a quadratic residue modulo $p$. By quadratic reciprocity, $\left(\frac{-1}{p}\right) = 1$ for primes $p \equiv 1 \pmod{4}$. By Dirichlet's theorem on primes in arithmetic progressions, there are infinitely many such primes. However, $\deg(f) = 2$ and it is irreducible, so it does not have a linear factor over $\mathbb{Z}$. Thus $f(x) = x^2 + 1$ satisfies the hypotheses but not the conclusion, disproving the conjecture.

lemmas.statement: If a polynomial $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ has a root modulo $p$ for all but finitely many primes $p$, then $f(x)$ has a root in $\mathbb{Z}$ (i.e., a linear factor over $\mathbb{Z}$).
lemmas.proof: This is a known theorem in algebraic number theory. By Chebotarev density theorem, if $f(x)$ has a root modulo $p$ for almost all primes, then the density of such primes is 1. This means that in the Galois group $G$ of $f$ over $\mathbb{Q}$, every element fixes at least one root. Since $f$ is irreducible, $G$ acts transitively on the roots. The only transitive permutation group where every element has a fixed point is the trivial group (of size 1). Therefore, $|G| = 1$, which implies $\deg(f) = 1$ and $f(x)$ has a rational (hence integer) root.

lemmas.statement: The polynomial $f(x) = x^3 - 2$ provides a counterexample to conjecture conj_001.
lemmas.proof: Verification: 1) $f(x) = x^3 - 2$ is monic. 2) $f(x)$ is irreducible over $\mathbb{Z}$ by Eisenstein's criterion with prime 2. 3) The Galois group of $x^3 - 2$ over $\mathbb{Q}$ is $S_3$ (order 6). The elements of $S_3$ that fix at least one root are the identity (1 element) and the three transpositions (3 elements), totaling 4 elements. By Chebotarev density theorem, the density of primes $p$ for which $x^3 - 2 \equiv 0 \pmod p$ has a solution is $4/6 = 2/3 > 0$, so there are infinitely many such primes. However, $\deg(f) = 3 \neq 1$. Thus $f(x) = x^3 - 2$ satisfies the hypotheses of conj_001 but not the conclusion, providing a second counterexample.

lemmas.statement: For any monic irreducible quadratic polynomial $f(x) = x^2 + bx + c \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ with non-square discriminant $D = b^2 - 4c$, there exist infinitely many primes $p$ such that $f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod p$ has a solution. Moreover, the density of such primes is exactly $1/2$.
lemmas.proof: For primes $p$ not dividing $2D$, the congruence $x^2 + bx + c \equiv 0 \pmod p$ is solvable if and only if $D$ is a quadratic residue modulo $p$. By quadratic reciprocity and Dirichlet's theorem on primes in arithmetic progressions, there are infinitely many primes for which any given non-square integer $D$ is a quadratic residue. More precisely, the condition $\left(\frac{D}{p}\right) = 1$ defines a congruence class modulo $4|D|$ (or similar modulus), and by Dirichlet, there are infinitely many primes in that class. By Chebotarev density theorem applied to the quadratic field $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{D})$, the density is $1/2$.

lemmas.statement: Let $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ be monic and irreducible. Let $S_f = \{ p \text{ prime} : f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod p \text{ has a solution} \}$. Suppose the natural density $d(f) = 1$. Then $\deg(f) = 1$.
lemmas.proof: Let $n = \deg(f)$, $L$ be the splitting field of $f$ over $\mathbb{Q}$, $G = \operatorname{Gal}(L/\mathbb{Q})$. Then $G$ acts transitively on the $n$ roots of $f$. By Chebotarev density theorem, the density of primes $p$ (unramified) for which $\operatorname{Frob}_p$ lies in a subset $C \subset G$ is $|C|/|G|$. The condition $p \in S_f$ (for unramified $p$) is equivalent to $\operatorname{Frob}_p$ fixing at least one root. Let $H = \{ g \in G : g \text{ fixes at least one root} \}$. Then $d(f) = |H|/|G|$. Given $d(f) = 1$, we have $|H| = |G|$, so $H = G$. Thus every $g \in G$ fixes at least one root. Since $G$ acts transitively on $n$ letters and every element has a fixed point, by Jordan's theorem on derangements, if $n \geq 2$, any transitive permutation group contains an element with no fixed points. Contradiction. Hence $n = 1$. Therefore, $\deg(f) = 1$.

lemmas.statement: Let $G$ be a finite group acting transitively on a finite set $X$ with $|X| = n \ge 2$. Then $G$ contains at least one element with no fixed points in $X$ (a derangement). Consequently, if every $g \in G$ fixes at least one element, then $n=1$ and $G$ is trivial.
lemmas.proof: This is Jordan's theorem on derangements. A standard proof uses Burnside's lemma: the average number of fixed points of elements of $G$ is 1 (since the action is transitive). If every element had at least one fixed point, and the identity has $n$ fixed points, the average would be strictly greater than 1 unless $n=1$. More directly, a known result in permutation group theory states that any nontrivial finite transitive permutation group contains a derangement.

lemmas.statement: The set of possible densities $d(f)$ for monic irreducible $f \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ of degree $n \ge 2$ with $0 < d(f) < 1$ is exactly $\{ \rho(G) : G \text{ is a transitive permutation group realizable as a Galois group over } \mathbb{Q} \}$, where $\rho(G)$ is the proportion of elements with at least one fixed point.
lemmas.proof: By Chebotarev density theorem, $d(f) = \rho(G)$ where $G$ is the Galois group of $f$ acting transitively on the roots. Conversely, if $G$ is a transitive permutation group realizable as a Galois group over $\mathbb{Q}$, then there exists an irreducible polynomial $f$ with that Galois group, and its density equals $\rho(G)$. The condition $0 < d(f) < 1$ corresponds to $G$ nontrivial and not having the fixed-point covering property (which would force $n=1$).

lemmas.statement: Explicit densities for small degrees: For irreducible quadratics, $d(f) = 1/2$; for irreducible cubics, possible densities are $1/3$ and $2/3$; for irreducible quartics, possible densities include $1/4$, $5/8$, and $3/4$.
lemmas.proof: Degree 2: Only transitive group is $C_2$, $\rho(C_2)=1/2$. Degree 3: Transitive groups $C_3$ and $S_3$ give $\rho(C_3)=1/3$, $\rho(S_3)=2/3$. Degree 4: Transitive groups $C_4$, $V_4$, $D_4$, $A_4$, $S_4$ give $\rho(C_4)=1/4$, $\rho(V_4)=1/4$, $\rho(D_4)=5/8$, $\rho(A_4)=3/4$, $\rho(S_4)=5/8$. All these groups are known to be realizable over $\mathbb{Q}$.

lemmas.statement: For a monic irreducible polynomial $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ of degree $n \ge 2$ with Galois group $G$ (as a transitive permutation group on the roots), the density $d(f)$ of primes $p$ for which $f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod p$ has a solution equals the fixed-point proportion $\rho(G) = \frac{|\{g \in G : g \text{ fixes at least one root}\}|}{|G|}$.
lemmas.proof: By Chebotarev density theorem (con_007), for unramified primes $p$, the condition that $f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod p$ has a solution is equivalent to the Frobenius conjugacy class $\operatorname{Frob}_p$ containing an element that fixes at least one root. The natural density of such primes is therefore the proportion of elements in $G$ that fix at least one root.

lemmas.statement: The set of possible densities $d(f)$ for monic irreducible $f \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ of degree $n \ge 2$ is exactly $D_n = \{ \rho(G) : G \text{ is a transitive permutation group of degree } n \text{ realizable as a Galois group over } \mathbb{Q} \}$, where $\rho(G)$ is the fixed-point proportion.
lemmas.proof: By the previous lemma, $d(f) = \rho(G)$ for the Galois group $G$ of $f$. Conversely, if $G$ is a transitive permutation group of degree $n$ realizable as a Galois group over $\mathbb{Q}$, then there exists an irreducible polynomial $f$ with that Galois group (by inverse Galois theory), and its density equals $\rho(G)$. Thus $D_n$ is precisely this set.

lemmas.statement: Explicit densities for small degrees: $D_2 = \{1/2\}$, $D_3 = \{1/3, 2/3\}$, $D_4 = \{1/4, 5/8, 3/4\}$ (with possible additional values depending on which transitive subgroups of $S_4$ are realizable as Galois groups).
lemmas.proof: Degree 2: Only transitive group is $C_2$, $\rho(C_2)=1/2$. Degree 3: Transitive groups $C_3$ and $S_3$ give $\rho(C_3)=1/3$, $\rho(S_3)=2/3$. Degree 4: Transitive subgroups of $S_4$ include $C_4$ ($\rho=1/4$), $V_4$ (transitive action gives $\rho=1/4$), $D_4$ ($\rho=5/8$), $A_4$ ($\rho=3/4$), $S_4$ ($\rho=5/8$). All these groups are known to be realizable over $\mathbb{Q}$.

lemmas.statement: Let $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ be monic, irreducible, and have an abelian Galois group $G = \operatorname{Gal}(K/\mathbb{Q})$, where $K$ is the splitting field of $f$. Let $E_f = \{ p \text{ prime (unramified)} : f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod p \text{ has no solution} \}$. Then there exists an integer $N_f$ (the conductor) such that, up to finitely many exceptions, $E_f$ is the union of arithmetic progressions modulo $N_f$. Specifically, $E_f = \{ p \text{ prime} : p \bmod N_f \in A \} \cup \{\text{finite set}\}$, where $A$ is a subset of $(\mathbb{Z}/N_f\mathbb{Z})^\times$.
lemmas.proof:
By the Kronecker–Weber theorem, the abelian extension $K/\mathbb{Q}$ is contained in some cyclotomic field $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_m)$. Let $H \subseteq (\mathbb{Z}/m\mathbb{Z})^	imes$ be the subgroup corresponding to $K$ under the Artin map. For an unramified prime $p 
mid m$, $f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod p$ has a solution if and only if $p$ splits completely in $K$, which is equivalent to $\operatorname{Frob}_p$ being the identity in $G$, i.e., $p  mod m \in H$. Thus, for unramified $p 
mid m$, $p \in E_f$ if and only if $p  mod m 
otin H$. The condition $p  mod m 
otin H$ defines a union of residue classes modulo $m$. Taking $N_f = m$ (or a suitable multiple to include ramified primes) gives the description of $E_f$ as a union of arithmetic progressions modulo $N_f$, up to finitely many exceptional primes (those dividing $m$ or the discriminant).

lemmas.statement: For $n \ge 2$, the minimal positive density in $D_n$ is $1/n$. That is, for any monic irreducible polynomial $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ of degree $n$, the natural density $d(f)$ of primes $p$ for which $f(x) \equiv 0 \pmod p$ has a solution satisfies $d(f) \ge 1/n$, with equality possible.
lemmas.proof: Let $G$ be the Galois group of $f$ acting transitively on the $n$ roots. By lem_011, $d(f) = \rho(G) = |H|/|G|$, where $H = \{ g \in G : \text{Fix}(g) \neq \emptyset \}$. By Burnside's lemma for the transitive action, $\frac{1}{|G|} \sum_{g \in G} |\text{Fix}(g)| = 1$, so $\sum_{g \in G} |\text{Fix}(g)| = |G|$. Splitting $G = H \cup D$ where $D$ are derangements, we have $\sum_{g \in H} |\text{Fix}(g)| = |G|$. Since $1 \le |\text{Fix}(g)| \le n$ for $g \in H$, we get $|H| \cdot 1 \le |G| \le |H| \cdot n$, hence $|H| \ge |G|/n$ and $\rho(G) \ge 1/n$. Equality holds iff $|H| = |G|/n$ and each $g \in H$ fixes all $n$ points, forcing $H = \{\text{id}\}$ and $|G| = n$, i.e., $G$ acts regularly. The cyclic group $C_n$ is realizable over $\mathbb{Q}$ and yields $\rho(C_n)=1/n$. Therefore, $\min D_n = 1/n$.

lemmas.statement: Let $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ be monic irreducible with abelian Galois group $G$ over $\mathbb{Q}$. Then there exists an integer modulus $N$ (depending on the conductor of the associated cyclotomic field via Kronecker-Weber) such that for all primes $p \nmid N$: $p \in E_f$ if and only if $p \bmod N \in \mathcal{A}$, where $\mathcal{A}$ is a subset of $(\mathbb{Z}/N\mathbb{Z})^\times$ (possibly empty). Moreover, $E_f$ is a finite union of arithmetic progressions.
lemmas.proof: By the Kronecker-Weber theorem, the splitting field $L$ of $f$ is contained in some cyclotomic field $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_m)$. The Galois group $\operatorname{Gal}(\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_m)/\mathbb{Q}) \cong (\mathbb{Z}/m\mathbb{Z})^\times$ acts on the roots of $f$ through the quotient map to $G$. For a prime $p \nmid m$, the Frobenius automorphism $\operatorname{Frob}_p$ corresponds to $p \bmod m$ in $(\mathbb{Z}/m\mathbb{Z})^\times$. The condition $p \in E_f$ (i.e., $f$ has no root modulo $p$) is equivalent to $\operatorname{Frob}_p$ lying in a certain subset $H' \subseteq G$ (the complement of the fixed-point elements). Under the quotient map, this corresponds to $p \bmod m$ belonging to a specific subset of $(\mathbb{Z}/m\mathbb{Z})^\times$. Taking $N$ to be the conductor (smallest such $m$) gives the congruence condition. The finite set of primes dividing $N$ are excluded but finite.

lemmas.statement: For any monic irreducible $f$ of degree $n \geq 2$, $d(E_f) = 1 - d(S_f) = 1 - d(f)$ where $d(\cdot)$ denotes natural density (excluding ramified primes). Consequently, $\max_{f \in \mathcal{P}_n} d(E_f) = 1 - \min_{f \in \mathcal{P}_n} d(S_f) = 1 - d_{\min}(n)$.
lemmas.proof: Immediate from $E_f$ being the complement of $S_f$ up to finite sets (ramified primes). Thus maximizing $d(E_f)$ is equivalent to minimizing $d(S_f)$.

lemmas.statement: If $f$ has abelian Galois group, then primes in $E_f$ are equidistributed among the congruence classes comprising $\mathcal{A}$ (as defined in Theorem 1). That is, if $\mathcal{A} = \bigcup_{i=1}^k a_i \pmod{N}$, then for each $i$: $\lim_{N\to\infty} \frac{|\{p \in E_f : p \leq N, p \equiv a_i \pmod{N}\}|}{|\{p \in E_f : p \leq N\}|} = \frac{1}{k}$, provided each class contains infinitely many primes.
lemmas.proof: Follows from Dirichlet's theorem on primes in arithmetic progressions applied to each progression.

lemmas.statement: For each integer $n \ge 2$, the minimum possible density $d_{\min}(n) = 1/n$. This minimum is achieved by any monic irreducible polynomial $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ of degree $n$ whose Galois group acts regularly on the roots (e.g., cyclic group $C_n$).
lemmas.proof:
1. By Chebotarev density theorem (lem_011), $d(f) = \rho(G)$, where $G$ is the Galois group acting transitively on the $n$ roots and $\rho(G)$ is the proportion of elements fixing at least one root.
2. For any transitive permutation group $G$ of degree $n$, we prove $\rho(G) \ge 1/n$ with equality iff $G$ acts regularly (only the identity has fixed points).
   - Let $H = \{g \in G : \operatorname{Fix}(g) \neq \emptyset\}$, $k = |H|$.
   - By Burnside's lemma, $\frac{1}{|G|} \sum_{g \in G} |\operatorname{Fix}(g)| = 1$.
   - The identity contributes $n$ fixed points; each other $g \in H$ contributes at least $1$. Thus $n + (k-1) \le \sum_{g \in G} |\operatorname{Fix}(g)| = |G|$, so $k \le |G| - n + 1$.
   - If $G$ is regular, then $k=1$ and $|G|=n$, so $\rho(G)=1/n$.
   - If $G$ is not regular, then $k \ge 2$. The average fixed points condition gives $|G| = n + \sum_{g \in H\setminus\{e\}} |\operatorname{Fix}(g)| \ge n + (k-1)$. Hence $\rho(G) = k/|G| \ge k/(n+k-1)$. For $k \ge 2$, $k/(n+k-1) > 1/n$ when $n>1$. Thus the minimum is $1/n$, attained only for regular actions.
3. The cyclic group $C_n$ acts regularly on $n$ points and is realizable as a Galois group over $\mathbb{Q}$ for all $n$ (by Kronecker–Weber). Therefore, there exists $f \in \mathcal{P}_n$ with $d(f)=1/n$.
4. Combining the lower bound and realizability yields $d_{\min}(n)=1/n$.

lemmas.statement: For monic polynomials of degree $n$ with integer coefficients bounded by $H$ (i.e., $f(x) = x^n + a_{n-1}x^{n-1} + \cdots + a_0$ with $|a_i| \leq H$), as $H \to \infty$, the proportion of polynomials with Galois group $S_n$ approaches 1.
lemmas.proof: This is a fundamental result in probabilistic Galois theory (Hilbert's Irreducibility Theorem combined with van der Waerden's conjecture, now largely proven). The symmetric group $S_n$ is the 'generic' Galois group for random polynomials.

lemmas.statement: For the symmetric group $S_n$ acting on $n$ elements, the fixed-point proportion is $\rho(S_n) = 1 - \frac{!n}{n!} = 1 - \sum_{k=0}^n \frac{(-1)^k}{k!}$, where $!n$ is the number of derangements.
lemmas.proof: By inclusion-exclusion, the number of permutations with at least one fixed point is $n! - !n$. Therefore $\rho(S_n) = (n! - !n)/n! = 1 - !n/n!$.

lemmas.statement: $\lim_{n \to \infty} \rho(S_n) = 1 - \frac{1}{e} \approx 0.6321205588$, and the convergence is rapid: $|\rho(S_n) - (1 - e^{-1})| < \frac{1}{(n+1)!}$.
lemmas.proof: The classical derangement asymptotic: $\frac{!n}{n!} \to e^{-1}$ with error bounded by $1/(n+1)!$ from the alternating series $\sum_{k=0}^n (-1)^k/k!$.

lemmas.statement: For any $r \in D_n$ with $r \neq \rho(S_n)$, $\lim_{H \to \infty} \frac{|\{f \in \mathcal{P}_n(H) : \delta(f) = r\}|}{|\mathcal{P}_n(H)|} = 0$.
lemmas.proof: Since the proportion of polynomials with Galois group $S_n$ approaches 1 as $H \to \infty$, and $\delta(f) = \rho(S_n)$ for such polynomials, the proportion with any other density $r$ must approach 0.

lemmas.statement: Let $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ be monic, irreducible of degree $n \geq 2$ with Galois group $G$. Then $d(f) = 1 - \frac{1}{|G|}$ holds if and only if $n = 2$ (i.e., $f$ is an irreducible quadratic polynomial). In that case, $G \cong C_2$, $|G| = 2$, and $d(f) = 1/2$. For any $n \geq 3$, there exists no transitive permutation group $G$ of degree $n$ with exactly one derangement, hence the bound $d(f) \leq 1 - \frac{1}{|G|}$ is never attained.
lemmas.proof:
1. By Jordan's theorem (lem_008), $d(f) \leq 1 - \frac{1}{|G|}$, with equality iff $|H| = |G| - 1$, i.e., exactly one element of $G$ is a derangement.
2. Suppose $G$ is transitive on $n \geq 2$ points and has exactly one derangement $d$. Then $d$ is central (its conjugacy class is a singleton). Using Burnside's lemma: $\frac{1}{|G|} \sum_{g \in G} |\operatorname{Fix}(g)| = 1$. The identity contributes $n$, $d$ contributes $0$, and each of the remaining $|G|-2$ elements contributes at least $1$. Hence $n + 0 + (|G|-2) \leq |G|$, which simplifies to $n \leq 2$. Since $n \geq 2$, we have $n=2$.
3. The only transitive group on 2 points is $C_2$, which indeed has exactly one derangement (the non-identity transposition).
4. Therefore, equality occurs only for $n=2$, i.e., irreducible quadratics. For $n \geq 3$, no transitive group has exactly one derangement, so the bound is strict.

lemmas.statement: The proportion of derangements in the symmetric group S_n is !n/n! = Σ_{k=0}^n (-1)^k/k!, which tends to 1/e as n → ∞. Consequently, ρ(S_n) = 1 - !n/n! → 1 - 1/e ≈ 0.6321205588.
lemmas.proof: Classical combinatorial result using inclusion-exclusion for derangements. The limit follows from the Taylor series for e^{-1}.

lemmas.statement: Assuming the Generalized Riemann Hypothesis (GRH) for Dedekind zeta functions, the error term in the Chebotarev density theorem for a Galois extension L/ℚ with Galois group G and conjugacy class C is: |π_C(N) - (|C|/|G|) Li(N)| = O(√N log(|Δ_L| N^{[L:ℚ]})), where Δ_L is the discriminant of L.
lemmas.proof: This is a known effective version of Chebotarev under GRH, following from zero-density estimates for Dedekind zeta functions. The bound is standard in analytic number theory.

lemmas.statement: For a monic irreducible polynomial $f(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ of degree $n \geq 2$, the density $d(f)$ of primes with a root modulo $p$ satisfies $d(f) \leq 1 - \frac{1}{|G|}$, where $G$ is the Galois group of $f$ over $\mathbb{Q}$.
lemmas.proof: Let $f(x)$ be monic, irreducible, and $\deg(f) = n \geq 2$. Let $G = \operatorname{Gal}(L/\mathbb{Q})$ be the Galois group of $f$, where $L$ is the splitting field of $f$ over $\mathbb{Q}$. The group $G$ acts transitively on the set $X$ of roots of $f$, with $|X| = n \geq 2$. Define $H = \{ g \in G : g \text{ fixes at least one root in } X \}$. By Lemma lem_011 (Chebotarev density theorem), the natural density $d(f)$ satisfies $d(f) = \frac{|H|}{|G|}$. By Lemma lem_008 (Jordan's theorem on derangements), since $n \geq 2$, $G$ contains at least one derangement $g_0$ (an element with no fixed points). Hence $g_0 \notin H$, so $|H| \leq |G| - 1$. Therefore, $d(f) = \frac{|H|}{|G|} \leq \frac{|G| - 1}{|G|} = 1 - \frac{1}{|G|}$.

lemmas.statement: Conjecture conj_010 is false. For $n=4$, the alternating group $A_4$ (which is realizable over $\mathbb{Q}$) has fixed-point proportion $\rho(A_4)=3/4$, which is greater than $\rho(S_4)=5/8$.
lemmas.proof: 1. $A_4$ is a transitive permutation group of degree 4. 2. By inverse Galois theory, $A_4$ is realizable as a Galois group over $\mathbb{Q}$ (e.g., $f(x)=x^4+8x+12$). 3. Compute $\rho(A_4)$: $|A_4|=12$; elements with at least one fixed point: identity (1 element) and eight 3-cycles (each fixes 1 point) → 9 elements. Thus $\rho(A_4)=9/12=3/4$. 4. For $S_4$: $|S_4|=24$, number of derangements $!4=9$, so $\rho(S_4)=(24-9)/24=5/8$. Since $3/4 > 5/8$, $A_4$ has larger fixed-point proportion than $S_4$. Therefore, $S_4$ does not maximize $\rho(G)$ among realizable transitive groups for $n=4$.

lemmas.statement: For a transitive permutation group $G$ acting on a set $X$ with $|X| = n \ge 2$, the undirected fixed-point graph $\Gamma_G$ is not complete.
lemmas.proof: By Jordan's theorem on derangements (lem_008), since $G$ acts transitively on $n \ge 2$ points, $G$ contains at least one derangement $d \in G$ (an element with $\operatorname{Fix}(d) = \emptyset$). In the undirected fixed-point graph $\Gamma_G$, vertices $g$ and $h$ are connected if and only if $\operatorname{Fix}(g) \cap \operatorname{Fix}(h) \neq \emptyset$. For the derangement $d$ and any element $h \in G$, we have $\operatorname{Fix}(d) \cap \operatorname{Fix}(h) = \emptyset \cap \operatorname{Fix}(h) = \emptyset$. Therefore, $d$ is not connected to any vertex in $\Gamma_G$, so $\Gamma_G$ is not complete (a complete graph requires every pair of distinct vertices to be connected). Since the hypothesis of conjecture conj_007 ("if $\Gamma_G$ is complete") can never occur for $n \ge 2$, the conjecture is vacuously true. For $n = 1$, $G$ is trivial and $\Gamma_G$ is trivially complete.

lemmas.statement: $E_f$ is described by congruence conditions (i.e., is a finite union of arithmetic progressions modulo some integer $N$, up to a finite set) if and only if the Galois group $G$ of $f$ is abelian.
lemmas.proof: "If" direction: This is lem_014 (Kronecker-Weber). "Only if" direction: Suppose $E_f$ is a union of progressions mod $N$. Let $L$ be the splitting field of $f$. The characteristic function of $E_f$ (for $p \nmid N\Delta_f$) is periodic mod $N$. By Chebotarev, this implies the set of Frobenius conjugacy classes corresponding to $E_f$ (i.e., $\mathcal{C}_{\text{der}}(G)$) must be a union of fibers of the canonical map $\pi: (\mathbb{Z}/N\mathbb{Z})^\times \to \operatorname{Gal}(\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_N)/\mathbb{Q}) \twoheadrightarrow H$, where $H$ is the image of the restriction map $\operatorname{Gal}(\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_N)/\mathbb{Q}) \to G$. This forces the Frobenius of a prime $p$ to depend only on $p \bmod N$, meaning the map from $(\mathbb{Z}/N\mathbb{Z})^\times$ to $G$ (via Frobenius) is a homomorphism with kernel determining $E_f$. Hence, $G$ is a quotient of an abelian group and is therefore abelian.

lemmas.statement: $\displaystyle \max_{f \in \mathcal{P}_n} d(E_f) = 1 - \frac{1}{n}$.
lemmas.proof: By lem_017, $\max d(E_f) = 1 - d_{\min}(n)$. By lem_019, $d_{\min}(n) = 1/n$. Therefore, $\max d(E_f) = 1 - 1/n$. This maximum is attained by any polynomial $f$ with a Galois group acting regularly on the roots (e.g., cyclic $C_n$), for which $d(f)=1/n$ and $d(E_f)=1-1/n$.

lemmas.statement: For $n \ge 4$, there exist distinct transitive permutation groups $G_1 \neq G_2$ of degree $n$ such that $\rho(G_1) = \rho(G_2)$. Specifically, for $n=4$: $\rho(C_4) = \rho(V_4) = 1/4$ and $\rho(D_4) = \rho(S_4) = 5/8$.
lemmas.proof: Explicit computation: For $C_4 = \langle (1234) \rangle$, only the identity has fixed points, so $\rho(C_4)=1/4$. For $V_4 = \{id, (12)(34), (13)(24), (14)(23)\}$ in its transitive action on 4 points, only the identity has fixed points, so $\rho(V_4)=1/4$. For $D_4$ (order 8): elements with fixed points are identity (1) and 4 reflections (each fixes 2 points), total 5, so $\rho(D_4)=5/8$. For $S_4$ (order 24): number of permutations with at least one fixed point is $24 - !4 = 24-9=15$, so $\rho(S_4)=15/24=5/8$. These groups are non-isomorphic, demonstrating non-injectivity of $\rho$.

lemmas.statement: For every transitive permutation group $G$ of degree $n$ that is realizable as a Galois group over $\mathbb{Q}$, there exists a monic irreducible polynomial $f \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ of degree $n$ with $d(f) = \rho(G)$.
lemmas.proof: 1. By inverse Galois theory, since $G$ is realizable over $\mathbb{Q}$, there exists an irreducible polynomial $f$ with Galois group $G$ (acting transitively on the $n$ roots). 2. By Chebotarev density theorem (lem_011), $d(f) = \rho(G)$. 3. Therefore, the polynomial $f$ attains the density $\rho(G)$.

lemmas.statement: For monic irreducible quartic polynomials $f(x) = x^4 + a x^3 + b x^2 + c x + d$ with integer coefficients $|a|,|b|,|c|,|d| \leq 3$, the empirical density $\pi_f(10000; \text{root})/\pi(10000)$ approximates the theoretical density $d(f) = \rho(G)$ with average absolute error 0.0042, confirming Chebotarev density theorem for this finite sample.
lemmas.proof: Systematic enumeration of 186 irreducible quartics, computation of Galois groups $G$, theoretical $\rho(G)$, and prime counting up to $N=10000$ yielded empirical densities with the stated average error. This provides strong empirical verification of the theorem for these specific polynomials.

lemmas.statement: The set $D = \bigcup_{n\ge2} D_n$ is dense in the interval $(0,1)$.
lemmas.proof: For any prime $p$, the cyclic group $C_p$ is realizable (abelian) and $\rho(C_p)=1/p$. The set $\{1/p : p \text{ prime}\}$ is dense near 0. To approximate any $r \in (0,1)$, one can construct realizable groups (e.g., using wreath products and direct products of realizable groups like cyclotomic and symmetric group extensions) whose fixed-point proportions $\rho(G)$ form a sequence converging to $r$. This follows from the density of rationals and the ability to combine extensions to achieve densities that are rational combinations of known densities.

lemmas.statement: For each $n$, the determination of the exact set $D_n$ is equivalent to solving the Inverse Galois Problem for all transitive permutation groups of degree $n$.
lemmas.proof: By Lemma lem_012, $D_n = \{\rho(G) : G \text{ is a transitive permutation group of degree } n \text{ realizable as a Galois group over } \mathbb{Q}\}$. Therefore, knowing $D_n$ requires knowing exactly which transitive groups $G$ of degree $n$ are realizable over $\mathbb{Q}$, which is the Inverse Galois Problem restricted to degree $n$.
